Murakami's father, Noboru Arthur Murakami, was a United States citizen born and raised in Los Angeles and nearby Terminal Island, California. He and his family were relocated by the Government to the Manzanar internment camp in the desert near Bishop, California pursuant to Executive Order 9066. Because the Court of Federal Claims correctly determined that Murkami was not entitled to compensation under the Act, we affirm. Arthur Murakami married Aiko Tani, who was also from Los Angeles.Around July 1944, the Government permitted Arthur Murkami to move to Chicago, but prohibited him from returning to the West Coast.Around February 10, 1945, Arthur MurKami received an individual exclusion order prohibiting him personally from returning.In a letter dated July 21, 1945 from the U.S. Headquarters Western Defense Command, Arthur Murphy's exclusion order was lifted.Murakami was born in Chicago approximately one month later, on August 23, 1945. His family moved from Chicago to Los Angeles approximately ten years later. Murakami and the Government filed motions for judgment on the administrative record. Court of Federal Claims granted the Government's motion but remanded the case to the Redress Office. Justice Department reconsidered Murakami's claim and concluded that he was still not entitled to a redress payment. 50 U.S.C.app.§ 1989b-4(h)(1) (2004).Evidentiary determinations by the Court of Federal Claims, including motions to supplement the administrative record, are reviewed for abuse of discretion. Air Land Forwarders, Inc. v. United States, 172 F.3d 1338, 1341 (Fed.Cir.1999). The Act was passed on March 21, 1942. The Justice Department promulgated regulations to implement the Act. The Act then defined eligible individuals: Any individual of Japanese ancestry who, during the evacuation, relocation, and internment period, was a United States citizen or a permanent resident alien. After January 20, 1945, individuals were generally free under the law to decide for themselves whether and when they should return to the West Coast. This is the basis for eligibility under Ishida, and the Department is bound by the court's strictures. An individual is found to be eligible if such an individual:Is of Japanese ancestry;  and was living on the date of enactment of the Act, August 10, 1988. Murakami argues that he is an eligible individual “otherwise deprived of liberty” under 50 U.S.C.app.§ 1989b-7. Murakami alleges that his situation is analogous to the appellant in Ishida v. United States, 59 F.3d 1224 (Fed.Cir.1995), because he was excluded from his parents' home of Los Angeles. Higashi was born on February 6, 1945, seventeen days after the Government's rescission of Executive Order 9066 became effective.Higashi argued that her family was constructively or actively restrained by governmental action after January 20, 1945. The court held that children born to parents of Japanese ancestry who were excluded from their family homes in prohibited military zones are entitled to compensation. In Ishida, this court interpreted the Act to extend compensation to newborns excluded by law from their parents original place of residence as a result of Executive Order 9066.Because all restrictions on travel and relocation were rescinded as of January 20, 1945 by Proclamation No.21, from that date forward newborns or other family members were no longer “excluded by law” from returning to their original residences. Murakami III, 52 Fed.Cl.at 236. Court of Federal Claims concluded that the Redress Office's approach appeared inconsistent with the plain language of 50 U.S.C.app.§ 1989b-7 that an individual is eligible for redress if deprived of liberty “as a result of” governmental laws or orders.Accordingly, the court remanded Murakami's claim to the Justice Department for a redetermination. Murakami was born several months after Executive Order 9066 was rescinded and more than one month after Arthur Murakami's individual exclusion order was lifted. According to the Justice Department, children born after the rescission are not eligible for redress payments. The Justice Department concluded that the Murkami family's decision not to return to the West Coast was solely a “personal decision” based on the family's lack of housing. The Act provides that U.S. citizens and permanent resident aliens are eligible for redress if they were “confined, held in custody, relocated, or otherwise deprived of liberty or property as a result of” certain enumerated governmental actions. According to dictionary definitions, the verb “result” commonly means “to proceed, spring, or arise as a consequence, effect, or conclusion” This language is naturally read simply to impose the requirement of a causal connection between the “injury” or “aggravation of an injury” and “hospitalization, medical or surgical treatment, or the pursuit of a course of vocational rehabilitation.” Brown v. Gardner, 513 U.S. 115, 119, 115 S.Ct.552, 130 L.Ed.2d 462 (1994). Other circuit courts of appeal have reached similar conclusions. The court also rejected Murakami's allegations that, even if not medically impractical, it was impossible for the family to wrap up their affairs in Chicago, find emp.at 351 n. 3. The court further concluded that Murkami's medical evidence, presented in a one-page declaration submitted by Aiko MurakAMI's doctor, Dr. Shigekawa, was conclusory in its hypothetical recommendation that she should not have traveled.

Brian Petty appealed the district court's summary judgment and judgment on partial findings in favor of Metropolitan Government of Nashville-Davidson County. Petty claims that Metro violated his rights under the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 (“USERRA”) The central dispute in this case is whether Metro violated USERRA in its treatment of Petty. Plaintiff's unit ran the camp on a day-to-day basis-moving supplies; setting out bottled water for soldiers;  handling any problems with housing, etc.The job also required Plaintiff to empty and store contraband from “amnesty boxes.” In June or July, 2004, Command Sergeant Thomas Seuberling conducted a health and welfare inspection of Plaintiff's quarters. During the initial inspection, CSM.Seuberling found a five-gallon jerry can that Plaintiff was using to manufacture homemade wine. Plaintiff's discharge was characterized as “under honorable conditions (general).”   The Army returned Plaintiff to Fort Stewart, Georgia on or about February 1, 2005. The Police Department's return-to-work process includes a personal history update questionnaire, a medical examination, a computer voice stress analysis, a drug screening, and a debriefing with a police psychologist. Lieutenant Howey prepared a report concluding that the allegation that Plaintiff was not truthful when he completed return-to-work paperwork was unfounded. Lieutenant Howey signed this report on May 17, 2005. Chief of Police Ronal Serpas accepted Mr. Howey's conclusions. On July 22, 2005, Ms. Sawyers sent Plaintiff a letter stating that OPA had completed its investigation and determined that the charges against him were unfounded. Petty v. Metro.Gov't of Nashville-Davidson, No.3:05-0680, 2006 WL 3333509 at *1-5, 2006 U.S. Dist.LEXIS 83787 at *2-16 (M.D.Tenn.Nov. 16, 2006) (internal citations omitted;  footnotes in original).Petty's complaint alleged that Metro violated his rights under USERRA. The nonmoving party must present sufficient evidence to create a genuine issue of material fact. A different standard is applied to the entry of a judgment on partial findings. The district court is not required to draw any special inferences, and it is permitted to weigh the evidence and resolve any conflicts therein. On appeal, we review legal determinations de novo and the relevant findings of fact for clear error.Sharp ex rel.Estate of Sharp v. United States, 401 F.3d 440, 443 (6th Cir.2005).III.STRUCTURE OF USERRA. Fourth, it prevents employers from firing without cause any returning veterans within one year of reemployment. At times, the interplay among these provisions has caused some confusion. We find that Petty is entitled to summary judgment with respect to his first two claims; the third, which we will analyze separately, is not properly asserted as a reemployment claim. Petty provided a form DD-214, which Metro concedes he provided. Metro argues that Petty's form did not include three fields at the bottom of the form. We conclude that it would be inconsistent with the goals of USERRA to prevent Petty from exercising his right to reemployment because he failed to provide forthrightly information. Petty's separation from military service is classified as “under honorable conditions,” which Congress has made clear suffices to qualify him for USERRA benefits. The district court determined that Metro's return-to-work procedures could be applied to Petty, finding that because they are applicable to all individuals regardless of military service, these procedures did not constitute “additional prerequisites.” The district court incorrectly characterized part of Petty's reemployment claim-that part dealing with the position to which he was reinstated- as being part of his discrimination claims and therefore held that it required a showing of discrimination. The Department of Labor specified that “[t]he employee is not required to prove that the employer discriminated against him or her because of the employee's uniformed service in order to be eligible for reemployment” Petty's alleged "dishonesty" cannot serve as a basis for delaying or otherwise limiting Petty's right to reemployment. Metro's attempt to impose additional prerequisites through its return-to-work process was, as we have already explained, wholly impermissible. “Prompt reemployment” means reemployment as soon as practicable under the circumstances. Metro has never proved Petty's disqualification for reemployment. The burden of proving that a returning veteran is not qualified falls on the employer, not on the employee. Section 4312 protects only a service person's right to reemployment, which in turn triggers § 4313's guarantee of the appropriate position of employment. Petty argues that claims for failure to rehire promptly and denial of his request to perform off-duty work constitute violations of USERRA's antidiscrimination provision. The district court erred in its legal analysis of this claim, and because it clearly erred. in its finding that no evidence in the record supported this claim. We reverse its judgment on partial findings. Metro argues that Petty was denied permission to engage in off-duty employment because he was being investigated at the time of his request. Metro argues that this second investigation, although indirectly involving his military service, is solely motivated by concerns for Petty's honesty and truthfulness. The district court concluded that “[t]he only evidence before the Court that [Petty]'s military status was a motivating factor in [Metro]'s decision is the opinion of [Pety] himself” This email establishes: (1) that after the first investigation was complete, there was still concern regarding Petty's conduct in service, not his honesty, amongst those who initiated the second investigation. (2) that the informal investigation that led to the second, formal investigation was quite possibly motivated by those concerns about Petty's military service.Indeed, Sawyers' testimony appears to confirm this latter point.

Jaimi L. Bowers worked at the Youngstown Air Reserve Station as a Logistics Support Specialist in the Logistics Readiness Squadron, 910th Maintenance Support Group. She was terminated from her position on August 15, 2005. She contends that she was wrongfully charged with being absent without leave and discharged on the basis of her gender, her disabilities, and in retaliation for filing a complaint. On March 31, 2009, the district court granted the Secretary's motion to dismiss Bowers' complaint. Bowers now appeals the dismissal of her complaint.Standard of Review: The parties and the court construed the Secretary’s motion as an attack on the factual basis for subject matter jurisdiction. In United States v. Johnson, the Supreme Court invoked the military discipline rationale underlying the Feres doctrine in a case involving negligence on the part of civilian employees of the government. The Court determined that the “unique disciplinary structure of the military establishment and Congress' activity in the field” constituted “special factors” making it inappropriate to allow a judicially-created remedy. The plaintiff's husband, a member of the Coast Guard, was killed when his helicopter crashed during a rescue mission. The plaintiff alleged that the crash resulted from the negligent actions of civilian radar controllers. The Court held that the plaintiff could not pursue her FTCA claim, in part, because:[M]ilitary discipline involves not only obedience to orders, but more generally duty and loyalty to one's service and to one’s country. This Court extended the analysis in Feres and Chappell to discrimination claims brought by military personnel pursuant to Title VII and the Rehabilitation Act in Coffman v. Michigan. The Court declined to limit Feres to claims by officers against their superiors because even an inquiry into whether a suit questions “military discipline and decisionmaking would itself require judicial inquiry into, and hence intrusion upon, military matters” This Court has reiterated the holding from Leistiko on several occasions. In Fisher v. Peters, the Court considered a Title VII claim by a National Guard technician who alleged that her supervisors had downgraded her performance appraisal and denied her requests for promotion. The Court affirmed a grant of summary judgment in favor of the defendant because the position is irreducibly military in nature. In the Fifth Circuit, only claims “arising purely” from the employee's civilian status may be brought. In the Ninth Circuit, dual status technicians are barred from bringing claims where “the challenged conduct is integrally related to the military's unique structure” The ART and National Guard technician positions are both subject to 10 U.S.C.§ 10216(a)(1), which provides:For purposes of this section and any other provision of law, a military technician (dual status) is a Federal civilian employee. The functions performed by ARTs and National Guard technicians, as described in the applicable statutes, are substantially the same. The “distinctively military tasks” noted by Wright in the National Guard Technicians Act are duplicated in 10 U.S.C.§ 10216(a)(1)(C) ARTs train reservists, provide continuity within the Reserve unit of assignment, and support the unit's gaining major command. The ART workforce provides stable, continuous full-time management, administration, and training of the Ready Reserve. ARTs oversee the transition from peacetime to a wartime or national emergency situation to ensure mobilization readiness. Bowers argues that the district court should have considered that ARTs are not required to wear uniforms while performing their civilian duties. Bowers cites McGinnis v. United States Air Force, 266 F.Supp.2d 748 (S.D.Ohio 2003), as evidence that there is nothing intrinsically military about the Logistics Management Specialist position. Bowers contends on appeal that Majors Sturdevant and Coburn did not supervise her in her military capacity. The Federal Circuit's analysis in Bowers v. United States, 450 F.3d 1342, 1342 (Fed.Circuit) found that the position of National Guard technician, as a whole, is irreducibly military in nature. Jentoft, 450 F.3d at 1343. The court reasoned that “there is no language in § 10216(a) limiting the circumstances in which a dual status technician can be considered a federal civilian employee” The Fifth Circuit has rejected the holding in Jentoft as applied to National Guard technicians and ARTs. In its previous cases, the Court acknowledged, along with every other circuit that has considered claims by dual status technicians, that National Guard technicians occupy a position with a civilian component. Bowers urges the Court to adopt the three-factor “incident to service” test used in Parker v. United States, 611 F.2d 1007 (5th Cir.1980), to determine whether an injured service member was barred from bringing an FTCA claim. Under Feres v. United States, 340 U.S. 135, 71 S.Ct.153, 95 L.Ed.152 (1950), and its corollaries, no cause of action exists for Bowers' allegations. Dismissal is appropriate for failure to state a claim, a result distinct from holding that the court lacks subject-matter jurisdiction.

Lance Corporal Aaron Schoenfeld lost his leg while a passenger in his roommate's car when it crashed into a previously damaged, but unrepaired, guardrail on a military base.The sole issue on appeal is whether the Feres doctrine, which immunizes the government from suit for injuries arising incident to military service, bars Schoenfield's claim against the government under the Federal Tort Claims Act. After the accident, Schoenfeld continued to receive his regular military salary until 2002, when he was placed on the Navy's Temporary Disability Retirement List. He is entitled to affordable healthcare and pharmacy services through the military's TRICARE program. He claims that he has not been reimbursed for several surgeries and that he was forced to purchase his own medical insurance. The government moved to dismiss the complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction. The FTCA is a broad waiver of the federal government's sovereign immunity. In Feres, the Supreme Court carved out a significant exception. “The Government is not liable under the [FTCA] for injuries to servicemen where the injuries arise out of or are in the course of activity incident to service.’ ” Costo, 248 F.3d at 866. In Johnson, an active duty Air Force sergeant moonlighted as a bartender in the Noncommissioned Officers Club (“NCO Club”) located on Malmstrom Air Force base in Montana. One night, Johnson and several other employees held a liquor-laden after-hours party until 4:30 a.m. Another employee, intoxicated, agreed to drive Johnson to his off-base home. About a mile outside the entrance to the base, Hay's vehicle was involved in an accident which resulted in Johnson becoming a quadriplegic. The government denied Johnson's administrative claim. He brought suit under the FTCA alleging that the government negligently allowed the NCO Club to stay open late in violation of Montana and military law. We held that Feres was inapplicable, noting that “the most persuasive [policy] justification for the Feres doctrine is the potential impact of civil suits on military discipline” Johnson thus strongly suggests that NCO Club positions were not actually available to civilians, but rather that the essentially non-military nature of the activity weighed against applying Feres. Johnson's activities could not have adversely affected military discipline for three reasons. He was “not subject in any real way to the compulsion of military orders or performing any sort of military mission” Dreier's widow sued under the FTCA, alleging the government knew that the area was hazardous but did nothing to make it more safe. We reversed the district court's ruling that Feres barred her suit. We reasoned that because civilians could gain access to the beach, Dreier's presence there made his activities “indistinguishable” from a civilian. In Bon, Janice Bon was an active duty member of the United States Navy.She was injured when a government motor boat struck a canoe she was rowing and had rented from the Navy's Special Services facility at the San Diego Naval Training Center.Bon was on authorized liberty at the time, though it is unclear for how long. Nollie Costo, a sailor in the United States Navy, drowned during a Navy-sponsored recreational white water rafting trip. While the actual rafting was off-base, the trip was part of the Navy's Morale, Welfare, and Recreation program, the “administration, supervision, and operation” of which was the ‘responsibility of cognizant commanding officers’ Coffey, 455 F.2d at 1380. Schoenfeld, an active duty marine, was on liberty from Friday afternoon until Monday morning. The district court assumed for purposes of the motion that the car in which Coffey rode was heading off-base for non-military purposes. Schoenfeld received substantial disability benefits from the military, a fact that weighs in favor of applying Feres. But riding along Stuart Mesa Road, which is partially open to the public, was not a privilege available to him because of his military status. A serviceman is not precluded from FTCA recovery merely because he receives disability benefits. In Millang, plaintiff's suit was Feres-barred in part because the picnic where the accident occurred was open only to servicemen and their guests. In Bon, we emphasized that Janice Bon was able to rent a canoe only because of her military status. In Dreier, the beach was open to civilians (with a permit) as well as servicemen. This case is unlike Bon, Costo, or McConnell, where the plaintiffs' military status afforded them access to certain privileges. Civilians and servicemen alike could drive on Stuart Mesa Road. Schoenfeld's activities leading up to his accident are not meaningfully distinguishable from those of a civilian.

Wayne G. Lovely, a former student at the University of Dayton (“UD”) and member of the Army Reserve Officers' Training Corps (‘ROTC’), brought claims against the United States of America and its agency. Lovely's claims were based on actions taken by Lovely's ROTC commander in relation to a UD disciplinary proceeding initiated against Lovely. The district court dismissed Lovely's IIED claim under the Feres doctrine. In January 2004, a female cadet reported to Washington that Lovely had sexually assaulted her in September 2003.She declined to press criminal charges, but accepted Washington's recommendation that she see a counselor at UD's counseling center.Upon the advice of Dr. Carol Cummins-Collier at the counseling center, the female Cadet decided to pursue proceedings against Lovely through the UD disciplinary board.A UD disciplinary-board hearing was scheduled for February 17, 2004.Lovely was suspended on March 8, 2005. Lovely was disenrolled from ROTC for misconduct, preventing any eligibility to re-enroll.Lovely filed a claim for damages with the Army, which was denied, primarily on the basis that Feres precluded Lovely, who was enlisted in the Army at the time of the alleged injury, from recovering for an injury incident to service. Congress created a waiver of sovereign immunity under which the United States may be held liable for “tort claims, in the same manner and to the same extent as a private individual under like circumstances.” The language of the FTCA exempts from this waiver of immunity claims “arising out of the combatant activities of the military or naval forces, or the Coast Guard, during time of war. Lovely argues that his claims are not subject to the Feres doctrine because he was not on active duty or subject to military command or discipline while attending classes at UD or while involved in the UD disciplinary proceedings. The Eighth and the Second Circuits have done so, concluding that the doctrine applied when the ROTC cadet's injuries occurred in the course of activity incident to military service. We conclude, however, that application of the Feres doctrine to Lovely's claim is supported by the third rationale stated in Johnson. Because Lovely's injuries stemmed from the manner in which his commanding officer chos.at 15, we conclude that the case should be dismissed.

Appellants filed a class action complaint against the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) on behalf of themselves and a putative class of veterans. The complaint alleged that the VA violated 11.C.A.§ 525 (West 2004 & Supp.2006), the anti-discrimination provision of the Bankruptcy Code. The district court granted the VA's motion to dismiss. The VA refused to extend full guaranty amounts to Appellants because it had suffered losses on previous loan guaranties made on their behalf that had not been repaid. The amount of guaranty available to a veteran upon a successive application for the benefit is reduced by the amount of loss that the VA suffered on any previous guaranty made on behalf of the veteran. 11 U.S.C.A.§ 1291 (West 2006).II. We review de novo the district court's grant of the VA's motion to dismiss made pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).Bominflot, Inc. v. The M/V Henrich S, 465 F.3d 144, 145 (4th Cir.2006). a veteran satisfying the length of service requirements is entitled to the loan guaranty benefit. Section 525(a)'s meaning is plain. The statute clearly specifies that its protections extend to “licenses, permits, charters, [and] franchises,” and to grants “similar” to those items. Although the term “grant” is not defined in the statute, the use of the word ‘similar’ limits the universe of ‘grants’ to which § 525(a) applies. Governmental entities issue real-estate, driver's, and medical licenses;  building and business permits; and corporate charters. All of these implicate “government's role as a gatekeeper in determining who may pursue certain livelihoods,” Toth v. Mich. State Hous.Dev.Auth., 136 F.3d 477, 480 (6th Cir.1998), and show that Congress intended the protections to be “limited to situations sufficiently similar to Perez” Appellants acknowledge that Goldrich's rationale is plainly at odds with their position on appeal, but they argue that Congress's enactment in 1994 of 11 U.S.C.A. rendered Goldrich a dead letter. Congress's tightly-worded abrogation of Goldrich’s specific holding “justif[ies] the inference that items not mentioned” were excluded by deliberate choice, not inadvertence. Appellants assume that the VA has deep pockets;  we assume that those pockets only function well when they do not have holes in them. The basic entitlement for any loan of more than $56,520 is the lesser of $36,000 or forty percent of the loan. The VA does retain some discretion in computing the aggregate amount of guaranty available. Omitting the word “similar,” Section 525(a) would present a “textbook ejusdem generis scenario.”  Andrews v. United States, 441 F.3d 220, 224 (4th Cir.2006) A veteran is only automatically eligible for a guaranty when a private lender concludes that the veteran meets the standards of creditworthiness-including debt-to-income ratio, income-stability, and monthly-income requirements-established by the VA. See 38 U.S.C.A.§ 3701(g)(2), (3) (West 2002).

Appellant Martin Gillan, IV was discharged from the United States Naval Reserve because he was twice passed over for promotion while classified as an active reservist.Gillan has challenged his discharge on the ground that the Navy should not even have considered him for a promotion and only did so because it had improperly failed to transfer him to an inactive status. Gillan was commissioned as a Coast Guard officer in 1978 and served on active duty as an aviator until he was honorably discharged in 1985 at the rank of Lieutenant. Gillan should have been considered for promotion turns on whether he was properly classified in an active status in the Ready Reserve or in an inactive status. Martin Gillan served in the Coast Guard Individual Ready Reserve from May 1985 until October 1987.Gillan then transferred to the Naval Reserve in late 1987 as a member of the Ready Reserve and was promoted to Lieutenant Commander in 1990.In December 1990, Gillan was activated for service in Operation Desert Storm.After hostilities ceased and effective May 31, 1991, he transfer to the Individual Ready reserve in an active status.At the time of this transfer, the Navy told Gillan that, if he wanted a category of lesser participation, he could request a transfer to Standby Reserve Inactive. Gillan never responded to this invitation. Naval Reserve Line Commander Selection Boards reviewed Gillan's file in April 1994 and April 1995 but failed to promote him to Commander. In 1997, two years after his transfer to an inactive status, Gillan tried to renew his activity in the Naval Reserve by participating in training drills. After Gillan participated in drills for five months, the Navy notified him in March 1998 that he could no longer participate in reserve activities because a Lieutenant Commander who twice fails selection for Commander must be discharged after twenty years of commissioned service. Gillan was honorably discharged on August 1, 2001. On a number of occasions, Gillan sought to have the Navy make this change to his 1990 fitness report and to vacate its decisions not to promote him, which would allow his continued service.He first petitioned the Navy in 1998.The BCNR considered and then rejected this request on June 24, 1999.Two subsequent petitions for rehearing were denied in 2001 and 2002 because Gillan failed to present new or material evidence that had not been previously considered.Gillan finally sought reconsideration in 2003. Gillan argues that 10 U.S.C.§ 12642(b) requires that the Navy conduct an annual screening of all reservists followed by an immediate transfer to inactive status of those who failed to qualify for active status. In Gillan's view of the statute, the Navy should have transferred him from the Ready Reserves to an inactive status earlier than it did. We review de novo the district court's grant of summary judgment for the Navy. Gillan argues that the word “shall” limits the Secretary's discretion. But nowhere does the statute impose a time requirement for such a transfer. Gillan's argument conflates the requirements of an annual “screening,” called for by Navy and Department of Defense regulations.

Rigoberto Aguilar-Turcios is a native and citizen of Honduras.He was admitted to the United States as a lawful permanent resident in 1996.While in the Marine Corps, he used a government computer to access pornographic internet sites.In 2003, he pled guilty to and was convicted by special court-martial of violating Article 92 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice (“U.C.M.J.”) Aguilar was convicted of violating Article 92 by violating or failing to obey a “lawful general order.”  A violation of either of these subsections requires conduct involving a visual depiction of a minor engaging in sexually explicit conduct. Aguilar's Article 92 conviction is not a categorical aggravated felony. The majority relies on our statement in Navarro-Lopez v. Gonzales, 503 F.3d 1063 (9th Cir.2007) (en banc), that we can never apply the modified categorical approach. The majority holds that our current precedent compels us to permit Aguilar-Turcios to remain in the United States. The petition for review and remand to the BIA with instructions to terminate the proceedings and order the government to release Aguilar. I dissent from the majority's application of this statement to the facts of this case because Aguilar-Turcios certainly was convicted of a crime that contained all the necessary elements of 18 U.S.C.§ 2252(a)(2), (4) I write to question our reliance on Navarro-Lopez's broad claim that we may never look to the modified categorical approach where the statute is missing an element of the generic crime. An “aggravated felony” includes offenses described in 18 U.S.C.§ 1101(a)(43)(I) (listing crimes relating to child pornography) Aguilar-Turcios pled guilty to violations of two broad provisions of the UCMJ. We analyze the Article 92 conviction as the only basis for removal. The majority finds that the Article 92 conviction lacks an element required by 18 U.S.C.§ 2252, namely proof that the pornography accessed by Aguilar-Turcios contained “a visual depiction of a minor engaging in sexually explicit conduct.” The majority, however, concludes that it cannot apply the modified categorical analysis because “the crime of conviction lacking an element of the generic crime” Chief Judge Kozinski's approach in Li is subject to criticism on a variety of fronts. It goes well beyond anything that the Supreme Court required in Shepard and Taylor. It is entirely inconsistent with almost two decades of Ninth Circuit precedent. It has created a jurisprudence of false-starts, conflicting decisions, and confusion. The approach in Li's concurrence is not so flexible. If a conviction is missing an element of the generic crime, a court can never look beyond the terms of the statute. This approach completely removes certain crimes from consideration in the immigration context. The result is that Navarro-Lopez makes an alien removable based more on geography than the conviction. There is no need to retry the facts of the conviction here because the plea colloquy, charging document, and stipulations of fact are undisputed in the record before us. A more flexible analysis is all the more appropriate in the present case because the reasons for adopting a strict reading of the Taylor categorical and modified categorical analysis are not implicated in civil removal proceedings. There is no doubt that Aguilar-Turcios is an alien, that he knowingly possessed images depicting a minor engaging in sexually explicit conduct, and that he was convicted under the UCMJ for that crime. Finding otherwise requires a significant indulgence of the “legal imagination.” The rule announced in Navarro-Lopez also conflicts with almost twenty years of Ninth Circuit jurisprudence. At least twenty-four published decisions from 1990 to 2009 have applied the modified categorical approach. Carrillo-Jaime v. Holder, 572 F.3d 747 (9th Cir.2009) (applying the modified categorical approach even though the California fraud statute does not require a showing that property was taken “without consent,” the second element of the generic “theft offense” described at 8 U.S.C.§ 1101(a)(43)(G));  Salazar-Luviano v. Mukasey, 551 F. 3d 857, 862-63 (9st Cir.2008) (Applying themodified categorical. approach to California's burglary statute, Aguilar-Turcios pled guilty to using a government computer to access pornographic websites. Nijhawan specifically holds that the loss requirement is not an element and that the framework from Taylor and Shepard does not apply to this portion of 8.S.C.§ 1101(a)(43)(M)(i) The only pornography that Aguilar-Turcios admitted to accessing on his government computer during the plea colloquy were the six images of child pornography. The military judge presiding over the plea proceedings carefully walked through all of the elements of what would be, in the civilian world, a conviction under 18 U.S.C.§ 2252. Aguilar also pled guilty to and was convicted by special court-martial of violating Article 134 of the U.S.C.M.J. He used two different computer hard drives, including the hard drive of the computer used in connection with his Article 92 conviction, to wrongfully and knowingly possess visual depictions of minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct. Navarro-Lopez has created a dramatic turnabout on this issue in our circuit. The UCMJ is thus best viewed as a parallel system of law enforcement, akin to a state criminal system. To conclude otherwise would be to render the immigration removal laws inapplicable. Some of the decisions cited in this Part, have been overruled or abrogated by the Court's recent decision in Nijhawan v. Holder. The statement in Navarro-Lopez conflicts with the approach taken by our precedent and sister circuits. See infra Part III.D.

Aguayo volunteered to serve in the U.S. Army in November 2002, when he was 30 years old. Aguayo committed to eight years in the Army, with four years of active duty, and entered service as a healthcare specialist in January 2003. In February 2004, shortly before he was deployed to Iraq, he applied for a discharge from the Army on the basis of conscientious objection. The Army denied his application, and he filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus in the district court. The court denied the petition, and Agayo now appeals. Aguayo's application was denied by the Department of the Army Conscientious Objector Review Board (“DACORB” or “Board”) in July 2004. In August 2005 Aguayo petitioned the United States District Court for the District of Columbia for a writ of habeas corpus ordering the Army to discharge him as a conscientious objector. The parties agreed to stay the proceedings in light of Aguaye's assertion that the Army had violated its own regulations by failing to provide him with the opportunity to rebut the negative recommendations from the officers in his chain of command. After exhausting all procedures for administrative relief, service members may challenge their custody by petitioning for a writ of habeas corpus in federal court. Aguayo's first argument concerns the DACORB's March 2006 supplemental memorandum, which lists several reasons for the Board's denial of Aguayo's application. Aguayo argues that, Habeas Rule 7 notwithstanding, courts may not consider new evidence in reviewing a conscientious objector habeas petition. We agree that the Army's decision to reject Aguayo's CO application must be supported by evidence in the administrative record. But the supplemental memorandum does not purport to contain such evidence. “Basis in fact” review in conscientious objector cases traces to the Supreme Court's 1946 decision in Estep v. United States, 327 U.S. 114, 66 S.Ct.423, 90 L.Ed.567. Estep was prosecuted for failing to submit to induction, and the Court held that he could challenge his military service classification. The Army defines conscientious objection as “[a] firm, fixed and sincere objection to participation in war in any form or the bearing of arms, because of religious training and belief.” The Supreme Court has stated that “the ultimate question in conscientious objector cases is the sincerity of the registrant” The review process relies heavily on the considered opinions of a number of officers. In this case, the DACORB ruled that Aguayo “did not present clear and convincing evidence ․ that the applicant's stated beliefs warrant award of 1-O sta.

Chi Tong Kuok was convicted after a jury trial on four counts of conspiracy and attempt to export defense articles. Kuok is a citizen of Macau, a special administrative region of the People's Republic of China. For roughly a decade, Kuok engaged in efforts to import protected defense articles from the United States into China. Kuok started his own business in 2000, installing and maintaining building management systems. A few years before he opened this business, Kuok developed contacts with a businessman who identified himself as a Chinese cultural official. Zheng began asking Kuok to buy items from abroad that could not be obtained in China. Kuok generally had no problems acquiring them, but troublingly, it would often take a long time for Zheng to pay Kuok back. Zheng refused to let him out of the deal, instead telling Kuok that he had no choice.In 2007, Kuok was diagnosed with a tumor and hospitalized for a week, again begging to be let out of Zheng's schemes, but still Zheng refused. Kuok made a Brady request for any materials in the government's possession that would support his duress defense. The government objected to the Brady request, and the district court denied it as untimely. Kuok argues that the Arms Export Control Act invalidly delegates legislative authority. The Constitution provides that “[a]ll legislative Powers herein granted shall be vested in a Congress of the United States” The Supreme Court has announced a nondelegation principle: “Congress may not constitutionally delegate its legislative power to another branch of Government” The AECA authorizes the President to maintain the United States Munitions List. The Supreme Court rejected a similar nondelegation challenge in United States v. Curtiss–Wright Exp.Corp., 299 U.S. 304 (1936) The AECA does not violate the constitutional prohibition on delegation of legislative power. Kuok challenges his conviction on the grounds that the AECA and its implementing regulations do not create liability for attempting to cause another person to violate it. The government argues that Kuok's case, because it involves conduct that occurred in part in the United States, does not invoke extraterritorial jurisdiction at all. A defendant can only be found guilty of an attempt to commit a federal offense if the statute defining the offense also expressly proscribes an attempt. For the government's theory to be viable, either 18 U.S.C.§ 2(b) would have to contain an attempt provision, or 22 C.F.R.§ 127.1 would haveto contain an attempted causation provision. Since neither statute does so, Kuok cannot be convicted on this count. Kuok challenges his conviction on count two because he argues that the government did not satisfy all of the elements of 18 U.S.C.§ 554. This count is based on Kuok's purchase of the Taclane encryptor. Kuok argues that competing definitions render the statutory text ambiguous and require application of the rule of lenity. Section 554(a) applies to anyone who “receives, [or] conceals] or buys” any merchandise, article, or object contrary to law. Kuok argues that the statute requires proof of his “intent to export.” The government argues that superfluity is not always to be avoided. Kuok argues that the jury instructions with respect to count one are invalid because they allowed the jury to convict based on the “attempt to cause an export” theory of count three. Because we have rejected his arguments and concluded that Kuok's conviction under § 554(a) need not be vacated as a matter of law, we disagree that the Jury instructions were improper. Duress is not a statutory defense, but a common-law defense that allows a jury to find that the defendant's conduct is excused. The burden of proof is on the defendant to show that: (1) he was under an immediate threat of death or serious bodily injury, (2) he had a well grounded fear that the threat would be carried out, and (3) he has no reasonable opportunity to escape. Kuok was told his wife would be arrested and disappear into a secret prison if he refused to cooperate.Kuok believed that Zheng represented the Chinese intelligence service, whose capacity to carry out its threats would be far greater than the run-of-the-mill criminal organization. Zheng knew his family's movements and other intimate details that demonstrated that his family was regularly monitored.

Frederick Aikens, formerly a colonel in the North Carolina Army National Guard, alleged that his former colleagues violated his Fourth Amendment rights by wrongfully intercepting, reading, and forwarding his e-mails while he was deployed in Iraq. The district court dismissed the action without prejudice, concluding that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction because of Colonel Aiken's failure to exhaust any available intramilitary remedies. Colonel Aikens filed a motion for relief from the judgment, pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b)(6) He argued that the judgment should be reopened because he had complied with the court's requirement that he exhaust his intra-service administrative remedies and he now might face a statute of limitations defense if he were to file a new action. Col. Aikens argues that the district court abused its discretion in denying him relief from its prior judgment of dismissal under Rule 60(b)(6) We agree that the issue was made directly addressed by the Supreme Court in a ruling that was made by procedural choices made by Aiken. Colonel Aikens asserts that his personal email was illegally intercepted and used to compel his retirement from the North Carolina Army National Guard (the “NCARNG”) after thirty-two years of service. Those responsible were NCARNG Adjutant General William E. Ingram, Jr., and Lieutenant Colonel Peter von Jess. The district court dismissed the § 1983 claim on the mistaken belief that Aiken was required to exhaust remedies with the Army Board for Correction of Military Records. Colonel Aikens filed a Rule 60(b) motion to seek relief from the ABCMR. The ABCMR determined that it was powerless to act because the relief sought therein was “not within [its] purview.” J.A.43. I cannot join the majority in affirming the denial of Rule 60 (b) relief in Colonel Aiken's request for new civil action. Colonel Aikens is seeking relief under Rule 60(b), which authorizes a court to relieve a party from a final judgment for “any other reason [not spelled out in clauses (1)-(5) ] that justifies relief” To be entitled to Rule 60 (b)(6) relief, the movant must demonstrate “extraordinary circumstances.” Col. Aikens' first timely attempt to have his case heard was dismissed for failure to exhaust intraservice remedies. His second attempt, this time before the ABCMR, as directed by the district court, was rejected. His third attempt, to revive his first lawsuit through Rule 60(b)(6), was denied. The court failed to acknowledge its primary role in creating the statute of limitations predicament. Colonel Aikens zealously objected to the proposition that ABCMR remedies were available and thus had to be exhausted. The federal courts may only forecast how the ABCMR might delineate its own jurisdiction, not define it for it. Colonel Aikens's statute of limitations quandary was the direct result of the district court's mistake, not any tactical decision made by Aiken and his lawyer. The majority merely speculates that its proposed strategies would have solved Akens's timeliness problem. The notion that Colonel Aikes could have initiated a new action is similarly speculative. The court may relieve a party or its legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons. The motion under Rule 60(b) must be made within a reasonable time-and for reasons (1), (2), and (3) no more than a year after the entry of the judgment or order or the date of the proceeding. Williams, 674 F.2d at 312-13 (concluding that court's purported error was not type of “mistake” that would justify clause (1) relief). Aikens filed his Rule 60(b) request within se.

Charles G. Willenbring was court-martialed in the late 1990s, while serving in the Army's reserve component. He was found guilty of three rape offenses committed in late 1980s, when he was serving in Army's regular component. In pursuing habeas corpus relief under 28 U.S.C.§ 2241, he contends that he was not subject to court-Martial prosecution. On appeal from the court-martial judgment, the Army Appeals Court affirmed Willenbring's convictions and adopted the military trial court's conclusion that he had not experienced a complete termination of service between his discharge from the Army's regular component on March 31, 1992, and his enlistment in the reserve component on April 1, 1992. On January 12, 2004, after exhaustion of his military court remedies, he petitioned in the Eastern District of North Carolina for habeas corpus relief, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.§ 2241. In June 2005, after the government moved for dismissal, the court dismissed the habea corpus petition. In 2007, Willen A “discharge,” in military terms, is generally understood to be a “complete termination” of military service, but does not include a discharge conditioned upon acceptance of further military service. Supreme Court's decision in United States ex rel.Hirshberg v. Cooke decided that the military was not entitled to institute court-martial proceedings against a servicemember for offenses committed during an earlier enlistment. Willenbring argues that Article 2(d) does not apply to his offenses because the phrase “on active duty”-in subpart (2)(A) thereof-refers only to those offenses committed while the servicemember was on active duty in the Army's reserve component. Willenbring relies for this proposition on the Third Circuit's 1996 Murphy decision. The Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces disagreed with Murphy's reasoning. 10 U.S.C.§ 101 provides a general definition of the term “active duty” applicable to all of Title 10, including the UCMJ. This definition thus encompasses active duty in both the Army's regular component and its reserve component. Congress expressly referenced the reserve component when it meant to restrict its application. In the late 1990s, Willenbring was indicted in North Carolina for six unrelated crimes-four rapes and two kidnappings-and the Army did not seek to exercise jurisdiction over those offenses. North Carolina placed him in pretrial confinement for those offenses on November 1, 1996, and later released him to the Army after the court-martial specifications were preferred. On January 8, 1999, he was convicted of the North Carolina charges and sentenced to life imprisonment, a sentence he is currently serving. Staff Sergeant Willenbring was initially sentenced, on October 14, 1998, to confinement for thirty-six years. Pursuant to a pretrial agreement, the military trial court later reduced his sentence to twenty years. The court-martial judgment is found at J.A.67. Willenbring II, 56 M.J. at 676. The Army Appeals Court further observed that “[t]here was no more a break in [willenbring's] service or status than there is a breakin time as one day or year turns to the next.”  Id. at 749, 95 S.Ct.1300.

Frank D. Wuterich is a Staff Sergeant in the U.S. Marine Corps who in November 2005 led a squad stationed in Iraq.On November 19, 2005, a roadside bomb detonated in the city of Haditha, killing two dozen Iraqi civilians.Wuterich filed suit against John Murtha, the Congressman from Pennsylvania's Twelfth Congressional District, for libel, invasion of privacy/false light, and republication of defamatory statements by third parties. Congressman Murtha's former Communications Director Cynthia Abram stated that three of the media interviews were taped in Pennsylvania when the Congressman “was in his congressional district during a district work period” Abram declaration stated that the interviews were not campaign related and explained that they were conducted in Congressman Murtha’s campaign office because that office was easily accessible to the broadcasters. The Federal Employees Liability Reform and Tort Compensation Act of 1988, commonly known as the Westfall Act, “accords federal employees absolute immunity from common-law tort claims arising out of acts they undertake in the course of their official duties”  Osborn, 549 U.S. at 229, 127 S.Ct.881. The Act's “core purpose,” as the Supreme Court has explained, ‘is to relieve covered employees from the cost and effort of defending the lawsuit’ Wuterich contends that we lack jurisdiction over this appeal, because the District Court's denial of certification pending discovery is not a “final decision” under 28 U.S.C.§ 1291. In this case, appellate jurisdiction arises pursuant to the collateral order doctrine of Cohen v. Beneficial Industrial Loan Corp. The Westfall Act confers absolute, not merely qualified, immunity upon federal employees acting within the scope of their official duties. The fact that the District Court denied the Government's certification pending discovery in no way limits Congressman Murtha's right to seek appellate review. The District Court's decision to deny certification was premised on an erroneous ruling that Wuterich was entitled to discovery. The Government certified that Congressman Ballenger was acting within the scope of his employment. The parties conducted limited discovery which was not an issue on appeal. Wuterich's claim that Congressman Murtha was “harping on Haditha as a way to embarrass the Defense Secretary’s wife” was insufficient to support a claim that the Congressman was acting outside thescope of his job. In Wilson, the court upheld the District Court's ruling that defendant Bush Administration officials had acted within the scope of their employment. Valerie Plame Wilson's husband Joseph C. Wilson IV had been an outspoken critic of the administration's approach to intelligence issues. The court explained that “[o]f course, the defendants may discredit public critics of the Executive Branch.”

The practice of specialized presidential intelligence briefing dates back to the administration of President John F. Kennedy.Because the PDBs were high-level intelligence documents, they were then and still are classified documents that are available only to the President and his senior advisors.Larry Berman, a political science professor at the University of California, Davis, filed a FOIA request seeking two Johnson-era PDB’s:  from August 6, 1965 and from April 2, 1968. Buroker states that the specific PDBs Berman requests “contain explicit references to information provided by foreign officials” Buroker warns that such information was provided “only upon a guarantee of absolute secrecy,” and disclosure “would tend to reveal the identities of intelligence sources.” The CIA must do more than show simply that it has acted in good faith. The CIA affidavit we rejected stated without justification that “disclosure of [the withheld] portions reasonably could be expected to lead to identification of the source of the information” Buroker's declaration provides the facts and reasoning upon which his conclusion is based. Berman objects to the CIA's reliance on the “mosaic theory,” which Buroker explains as the concept that some information in specific PDBs may appear harmless to disclose when read in isolation. The Supreme Court endorsed the mosaic theory in Sims, commenting that[B]its and pieces of data may aid in piecing together bits of other information. Berman's request relies heavily upon the assumption that the passage of time-around 40 years-has eroded any support for the assertion that the PDBs contain information about sources or methods that has not already been revealed. Buroker explains, however, that the passing of time has not vitiated the CIA's interest in maintaining the secrecy of the requested P DBs. In that case the district court held that exemption 3 excused the CIA from disclosing its budget. There, as here, it was the content of the documents sought, not the documents themselves, that deserved protection under exemption 3. We reject the CIA's argument that the PDBs are themselves protected intelligence methods.

Rhodes and Air America moved for summary judgment after CACI sued them for defamation. The district court granted the motion, concluding that Rhodes's statements were protected by the First Amendment. We affirm that Rhodes relied on a number of reputable sources, including two U.S. Army reports and the statements of an army brigadier general. Sources included two official military reports, a published interview of the brigadier general formerly in charge of U.S. prisons in Iraq (including Abu Ghraib), news articles, and a journalist's speech. Rhodes made the statements on her show in August 2005 that CACI challenges as defamatory. The Fay/Jones report detailed forty-four incidents of abuse inflicted by both military and civilian contractor (CACI and Titan) personnel. CACI or Titan employees were responsible in over one-third of the incidents. The report concluded that many of the Abu Ghraib abuses cited could be criminal, and it recommended that its findings with respect to three CACi employees and two Titan employees “be forwarded to the Army General Counsel for determination of whether [the employees] should be referred to the Department of Justice for prosecution. The Pentagon's widespread use of military contractors in Iraq attracted scholarly and media attention prior to and while Rhodes was airing her shows that are the subject of this case. Rhodes devoted parts of her show to the abuses at Abu Ghraib, the issue of military contractor responsibility for those abuses. Statement 4, August 22, 2005 (unregulated contractors and contractor employees): What's sickening is if you're a mercenary, if you go to work for Triple Canopy or Blackwater, first of all, there's no laws. You'll never, ever, ever be court-martialed. You can do any damn thing you want to. Karpinski: "Contractors were the ones that were actually doing the bad stuff" "They were like walking billboards for tyranny, for treachery, for murder!" "I really am annoyed that this thing that's being passed on, the cost, for Iraq I'm still going to pay for once I'm older" CACI sued Rhodes and Air America for defamation under Virginia law. CACI alleges that Rhodes's statements on her show accuse the company of, among other things, torture, rape, murder, and misrepresenting its authority at the Abu Ghraib prison. Rhodes made the statements with reckless disregard as to whether they were false. The First Amendment provides protection for statements that cannot ‘reasonably [be] interpreted as stating actual facts’ about an individual. This safeguard includes protection for “rhetorical hyperbole, a vigorous epithet’ and “loose, figurative, or hyperbolic language’ Rhodes joined in just such a discussion in this instance. CACI contends that the fact that its employees issued instructions to soldiers is irrelevant. CACI argues that Rhodes's sources gave her “no basis whatsoever” for accusing employees of misrepresenting their authority to soldiers or impersonating officers. The district court concluded that the two military reports, together with other sources, support the district court's determination. CACI argues that abuse is not a synonym for torture and that Rhodes must be held to have accused CACI of torture in the sense that word is used in the U.S. criminal code. Rhodes maintains that she used the word “torture” in statement 1 to describe the severe abuse that CACi bore responsibility for at Abu Ghraib, according to her sources. The Fay/Jones report detailed forty-four incidents of abuse at Abu Ghraib, finding that CACI employees were involved in nine. The report recommended that its findings with respect to three CACi employees be forwarded to the Army General Counsel for potential referral to the Department of Justice for prosecution. Rhodes's accusation about child rape has two components:  that children were raped at Abu Ghraib and that CACI bore responsibility for the rape. The First Amendment bars liability for such a defamatory accusation absent clear and convincing proof that the speaker made the accusation “with reckless disregard of whether it was false or not” In statement 4 Rhodes suggests-tongue in cheek-that anyone wishing to torture, kill, or murder should go to work for one of the contractors such as Triple Canopy, Blackwater, CACI, or Titan. The district court concluded that Rhodes's characterizations of Iraq as having “deteriorated into contractor heaven” with “[m]ercenaries all over the country, killing people” (statement 10), J.A.217, and characterizing a list of contractors as “hired killers” were “quintessential examples of hyperbole” Rhodes's statements were “immune from defamation liability” because the reasonable listener would understand that they were not stating actual facts about CACI itself. The district court concluded that Rhodes's purpose in making statements 3 and 12 was to advance a strong and vivid argument that the U.S. government should not use military contractors in Iraq. Rhodes was not saying that CACI committed murder at Abu Ghraib. She simply provided an open-ended list of potential targets for investigation without assigning blame to any particular contractor. Rhodes would not have been speaking with reckless disregard for the truth if she had suggested that CacI was responsible for murder.

Dr. Evelyn Lewis (“Lewis”) appeals the decision of the Court of Federal Claims denying relief from the Secretary of the Navy's decision to delay her promotion and subsequently to remove her name from a military promotion list.Lewis urges that she was promoted as a matter of law under 10 U.S.C.§ 624, and also that the Board of Correction for Naval Records' decision to deny her promotion was based on an incorrect interpretation of 10.S.-1094(a)(1) (2000) Lewis v. United States, 67 Fed.Cl.158, 163 (2005), was a case in the Court of Federal Claims. Lewis alleged that she was promoted to the rank of Captain as a matter of law by operation of section 624(d) She also contended that she. was denied promotion based upon an erroneous interpretation of section 1094. Fisher v. United States, 402 F.3d 1167, 1180-81 (Fed.Cir.2005) (en banc) (noting that the question of “who should be allowed to serve on active duty, and in what capacity” is generally nonjusticiable) The Constitution expressly provides that only the President has the authority to appoint an officer, and thus to take the final step in the promotion process. Lewis contends that the DoD policy of requiring all physicians to carry an unrestricted license is inconsistent with section 1094. In Lewis' view, a physician only provides health care as a physician if he or she provides direct patient care. Lewis does not contend that her duties were unrelated to the provision of health care. Section 1552 of title 10 gives the military secretaries power to correct military records using civilian boards. It provides that “[t]he Secretary of a military department may correct any military record of the Secretary's department when the Secretary considers it necessary to correct an error or remove an injustice”

A foreign government is a third-party beneficiary of a contract for military goods between the United States and a domestic military contractor. The foreign government agreed to purchase those goods from the U.S. under the Foreign Military Sales program. This case involves auxiliary output chips (“AOCs”) for use in certain global positioning satellite (‘GPS’) devices. Trimble I, 422 F.3d at 167. UK MOD claimed that Trimble breached its contract with the United States and that this breach harmed UK MOD. Trimble argued that the district court lacked subject jurisdiction because the Contract Disputes Act was not applied. The district court remanded the case for consideration. We review de novo a district court's dismissal for failure to state a claim under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) We accept as true all well-pleaded allegations and view the complaint in the light most favorable to the plaintiff. The appropriate test under federal common law for third-party beneficiary status is whether the contract reflects the intention of the parties to benefit the third party. In most cases, the choice between proceeding via FMS or DCS is a strategic decision based upon the needs of the foreign purchaser or defense contractor. UK MOD purchased goods that were only available via the FMS program. Recognition of UK MOD as a third-party beneficiary of the U.S.-Trimble agreements would be contrary to the AECA because it would afford UK MOD a right exclusive to DCS transactions. UK MOD cannot establish that it was a third-party beneficiary to any of the Trimble-United States agreements. We affirm the district court's decision to grant Trimble's motion to dismiss. We remanded for further proceedings on this issue, including a determination of whether the parties to the contract intended to bestow a benefit on a third party. Trimble contends that where procurement is required to fulfill the terms of a Letter of Agreement, the “back-to-back” contract structure necessarily precludes the third-party beneficiary theory being asserted by UK MOD. The mere fact that a procurement for cash does not involve a direct contractual relationship between the foreign purchaser and the defense contractor does not dictate that UK MOD's claim is statutorily barred.

Former Superintendent of the Virginia Military Institute appeals court's ruling. Court: General Bunting is entitled to qualified immunity. VMI is a state-operated military college located in Lexington, Virginia. Military regulations, etiquette, and drills pervade the VMI system, the court says. The Corps must remain standing and silent while the supper prayer is read, but cadets are not obliged to recite the prayer, close their eyes, or bow their heads. The Plaintiffs filed their complaint in the Western District of Virginia, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, along with nominal damages, costs, and attorney's fees. On January 24, 2002, the district court entered summary judgment in favor of the Plaintiffs. The court concluded that General Bunting was entitled to qualified immunity. When a case has become moot after the entry of the district court's judgment, an appellate court no longer has jurisdiction to entertain the appeal. When students challenge the constitutionality of school policies, their claims for declaratory and injunctive relief generally become moot when they graduate. Graduated students often maintain that their claims fall under an exception to the mootness doctrine. Plaintiffs' claims for declaratory and injunctive relief have become moot through happenstance, we vacate the district court's judgment insofar as it awarded such relief. The damage claim continues to present a live controversy. The court concludes that General Bunting “is entitled to the defense of qualified, good faith immunity.” In Wallace v. Jaffree, 472 U.S. 38, 105 S.Ct.2479, 86 L.Ed.2d 29 (1985), the Court invalidated an Alabama statute mandating a moment of silence in the state's public schools “for meditation or voluntary prayer.” In Wallace, the Court applied the test first enunciated in Lemon v. Kurtzman. In Lee v. Weisman, the Court invalidated a school's practice of inviting a member of the clergy to deliver a nonsectarian prayer at a commencement ceremony. The dominant factor guiding the Court's decision in Lee was the coercive nature of the religious activity. The Court concluded that, even though the students made the decision about whether to pray, the school had created the mechanism by which the decision was made. VMI's pregame prayer had an unduly coercive effect, and that the school had accordingly violated the Establishment Clause. General Bunting contends that we need not reach the “clearly established” prong of the qualified immunity analysis because the Establishment clause does not prohibit VMI's supper prayer. The General insists that prayer before meals is part of the fabric of society. General Bunting suggests that we should view the prayer as a uniquely historical practice. In Marsh, though, the Court was specifically influenced by the fact that, in September of 1789, members of the first Congress voted to submit the First Amendment to the states. The Supreme Court has since emphasized that Marsh is applicable only in narrow circumstances. VMI's cadets are mature adults, who will not feel coerced to participate in the supper prayer. General Bunting suggests that the members of the Corps (other than the rats) may avoid the prayer by falling out of the SRC formation before the Corps enters the mess hall. VMI's children are not unduly influenced by prayers of the sort in question here. At VMI, even upperclassmen must submit to mandatory and ritualized activities, as obedience and conformity remain central tenets of the school's educational philosophy. In this context, VMI's cadets are plainly coerced into participating in a religious exercise. VMI cannot avoid Establishment Clause problems by simply asserting that a cadet's attendance at supper and his or her participation in the supper prayer are “voluntary” In assessing General Bunting's asserted purposes for the supper prayer, we are concerned that he seeks to obscure the difference between educating VMI's cadets about religion and forcing them to practice it. When a state-sponsored activity has an overtly religious character, courts have consistently rejected efforts to assert a secular purpose. In establishing its supper prayer, VMI has done precisely what the First Amendment forbids. VMI's sponsorship of the supper prayer also brings the school into conflict with Lemon 's third prong, excessively entangling it with religious activity. The Establishment Clause protects the government from governmental interference with religious expression. General Bunting is immune from damages unless he violated “clearly established statutory or constitutional rights of which a reasonable person would have known.” The Establishment Clause plainly forbids public schools from sponsoring an official prayer for young children. The Supreme Court has never addressed the constitutionality of state-sponsored prayer.

Jerome Maher entered the Naval Reserves in 1987. He was hired by the City in its Aviation Department in August 1990. In February 1991, Maher was called to active duty in the first Gulf War. When Maher returned to work in September 1991, he was appointed “Director of Revenue” with a salary of $49,440. In 1993, Aviation was reorganized, and Maher was given a new title:  “Manager of Finance”   His salary increased to $54,840 per year. In January 1998, the City ordered Maher to transfer to Landside Operations (Landside is a division of Aviation) Maher argues that the magistrate judge erred by concluding that laches barred his 1991 claim. On appeal, however, Maher does not challenge the magistrateJudge's alternative holding that Maher failed to create a genuine issue of material fact regarding whether he had suffered an adverse employment action in 1991. Maher's 1992 DOL complaint should have put the City on notice that a suit was forthcoming, he argues.Leonard offers no support for such a delay.Maher contends that during the second trial the magistrate judge erred by excluding evidence of the alleged demotions in 1991 and 1993.

Erlinda Clamor appeals the district court's dismissal of her tort claim which arose from a car accident on the Pearl Harbor Naval Base with James Karagiorgis, a civilian employee. The district court concluded that Karagiors had been acting within the scope of his employment as a federal employee at the time of the accident. Erlinda Clamor was injured on a military base in a minor car accident caused by another government employee.Her state court lawsuit was removed to federal district court by the United States. The district court dismissed the case because Mrs.Clamor failed to exhaust her FTCA remedies before bringing suit. The case was reversed and remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion. The Government moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction based on Clamor's failure to exhaust her federal administrative remedies. The district court granted the motion. The Attorney General may certify that a federal employee was acting within the scope of his employment at the time of the incident giving rise to liability. Kang recognized that the mere fact that an employee was translocated to Hawaii for an indefinite period by his employer is not sufficient (by itself) to impose respondeat superior liability. In Kang, the employee had moved his belongings (including shipping at personal expense his own car) to the island of Kauai, had consumed several beers after work, and, hours later, was involved in a serious car accident while driving his own vehicle to a non-work-related dinner. Karagiorgis's conduct satisfies all three.

Vincent Staub sued the Proctor Hospital of Peoria, Illinois, under the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act. Staub alleged that the reasons given-insubordination, shirking, and attitude problems-were just a pretext for discrimination. A jury sided with Staub, and the district court denied Proctor's renewed motion for judgment. Staub's military duty had been a strain on the department. Angio techs were trained to work in both units and therefore had the ability to help out with radiology and the like when the need arose. On January 27, 2004, Mulally gave Staub a warning accusing him of shirking his duties. Staub and Sweborg worked together in the angio department all morning, finishing up around lunchtime. Staub walked to Korenchuk's office to tell him that he and S weborg were going to lunch. Korenukch wasn't there, so Staub left a voice mail informing him they were off to the cafeteria. 30 minutes later, KorenUkch showed up, demanding to know where they had been. He said he was “looking all over” for Staub, and Staub's explanation-that they were only at lunch and left aVoice mail-appeased him little. He escorted Staub down to Buck's office in Human Since Buck was the decisionmaker and there was no evidence she had a problem with Staub on account of his membership in the Reserves, Staub was out of luck under the traditional rubric. Staub sought to attribute Mulally's animus to Buck, and therefore to Proctor. Proctor argues on appeal that the district court mishandled the cat's paw theory. We were, and remain to this day, unprepared to find an employer liable based on a nondecisionmaker's animus unless the “decisionmaker” herself held that title only nominally. If the decision-maker wasn't used as a cat's paw-if she didn't just take the monkey's word for it, as it were-then of course the theory is not in play. We affirmed this principle in Metzger v. Illinois State Police. A new trial is not warranted where the properly considered evidence is insufficient to support the jury's verdict. A reasonable jury could not find that Mulally (or anyone else) had singular influence over Buck. Buck looked beyond what Mulally and Korenchuk said and determined that Staub was a liability to the company. Staub was reinstated after filing a grievance, but with certain conditions in place. Those conditions addressed perceived weakness in availability, attitude, and communication. For instan, Staub was placed on administrative leave. For more on this story, visit CNN.com/Impact.

Graylon L. Walch brought suit based on his discharge from the Texas Air National Guard and the loss of his position as a full-time National Guard civilian employee. The district court found the claims to be non-justiciable. The opinion issued in this case on June 6, 2008 is withdrawn and this revised opinion is substituted. Major Walch appealed a district court decision dismissing his claims. The 5th Circuit said the district court erroneously concluded that his claims were non-justiciable. The court also held that dismissal was warranted because Major Walch “fail[ed] to state a claim upon which relief may be granted” Major Walch alleged race and sex discrimination while a federal technician and a member of the Texas National Guard. Walch claims he was the victim of retaliation and that his dismissal from the Guard and the loss of his civilian position were similarly motivated. He is seeking reinstatement, back pay, money damages for the discrimination, and attorneys' fees. The court has jurisdiction under 42 U.S.C.§§ 2000e-5 & 2000e-16. The National Guard Technicians Act of 1968 created an unusual status, mixing state command with federal employment. Congress sought to recognize both the military and state characteristics of the National Guard by providing administrative authority to the states over the technicians. The Feres doctrine was premised on the disruptive nature of judicial second-guessing of military decisions. Major Walch's claims relate to his dual-status service, all arose on Air Force bases or other military locations.Technicians have a dual status.It is not possible to disentangle for these purposes their military role and command structure from their civilian employment. Congress has permitted Title VII claims to be brought by National Guard technicians. There are categories of employees of a state military department other than those involved in the precedents we have discussed. In Meister, the plaintiff was not a dual-status federal technician. Though she separately also served as a traditional Guard member, it was during her week-day civilian job at the Adjutant General's Department that she brought suit. Two judges agreed that Title VII claims by a National Guard technician were justiciable unless they were integrally related to the military. The Federal Circuit concluded that a 1996 statute, which said a technician was a “Federal civilian employee,” affected the applicability of Feres to statutory claims of discrimination. Major Walch claims a conspiracy by various members of the Texas National Guard. The alleged injuries all involve exempt personnel decisions. Walch argues that he was entitled to a board hearing, citing Cole v. Tex.Army Nat'l Guard, 909 S.W.2d 535 (TexApp.1995). Gough v. State, 2002 WL 90930 (Tex.App.Jan.25, 2002) (unpublished) (citing Tex.Adjutant Gen'l Reg.635-100).We find the Gough analysis convincing even if it is not a precedential explanation of Texas law.Compare Cole, 909 S.W.2d at 537 with Tex.Gov't Code Ann.§ 431.042 (Vernon 2005)

Albert L. Wilson seeks review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims on his application for fees and expenses pursuant to the Equal Access to Justice Act (“EAJA”) The Court granted his application, but awarded less than the amount he requested for the non-attorney practitioner who had worked on his case. After issuing its initial decision in Mr. Wilson's case in December 2002, the court lifted the stay in the Abbey case and ordered the parties to submit briefing explaining why the prevailing market rate for Mr. Stewart's services should not be $90 per hour. After receiving the parties' submissions, the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims in September 2003 granted Mr. Abbey's EAJA application in full, including fees for work performed by Mr.Stewart at the rate of $120 per hour, again at the $120 hourly rate. The Secretary did not appeal the Abbey and Pentecost decisions to this court. 38 U.S.C.A.§ 7292 (West 2002 & Supp.2004) (emphasis added) The emphasized phrase was added to the statute by section 402 of the VBA. The court considered that its jurisdictional grant regarding review of decisions of the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims was basically “issue jurisdiction.” The Government urges us not to consider the merits of Mr. Wilson's appeal on two grounds. First, according to the Government, Congress did not intend section 403 of the VBA to apply “retroactively” Second, as a prudential matter, this court should not address issues that were not properly raised below. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims wrongly failed to consider the effect of section 403 of the VBA on its determination of the appropriate fee for the non-attorney practitioner employed by Mr. Wilson. We vacate the decision below and remand for the Court of appeals to reconsider the appropriate hourly rate for Mr. Stewart's time.

Robert G. Smith is an ophthalmologist who served for more than 20 years in the United States Army.Dr. Smith was promoted to the rank of major in 1983 and to lieutenant colonel in 1990.Beginning in 1995 he was considered for promotion to colonel.The colonel selection board declined to promote him at that time, and he failed selection before each succeeding board until his retirement in 1999. Dr. Smith argues that the relief he was seeking was primarily equitable in nature, and that for that reason the district court had jurisdiction over his action. The Tucker Act grants the Court of Federal Claims jurisdiction to render judgment against the United States for damages on various types of claims, including any non-tort claim founded on the Constitution. The court explained that the availability of ancillary. equitable remedies under the Tucker Act meant that the. Court of Federal Claims could provide. an adequate judicial remedy for claimants seeking back pay under that Act. Dr. Smith contends that his complaint does not include a request for. monetary damages because he is not exclusively, or even principally, concerned with. the issue.
