There are two recognized exceptions to that general rule. The first exception does not apply in this case, because there is no suggestion that Dr. Smith enjoyed a clear-cut legal right to promotion to the rank of colonel. For the second exception to apply, a service member's discharge must be involuntary. 685 F.2d at 413. In this case, as in Koster, the service member's eligibility to continue in service was based on the length of his service, not the number of times he had been passed over for promotion.Accordingly, if Dr. Smith was required to reti
in all other respects,both the judgment and the order denying an award of attorney fees to plaintiff under section are affirmed.each side shall bear its own costs on appeal.

This appeal requires us to assess whether the Army complied with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (“NEPA”), 42 U.S.C.§§ 4321-4347 (2006), in planning its programs to modernize and streamline its forces. While the metamorphosis of the Army and the strategic planning accompanying this transformation is the business of. the Army, the Army's compliance with NEPA does involve us. The Army did not invite state and local agencies to participate in scoping for the PEIS. The Army noted internally that there was “[v]irtually no public response to ‘scoping.’” The Army provided notice of the pending PEIS in the Federal Register and in USA Today, not in the Hawaiian media. The Army's own experts recognized the shortcomings of the PEIS and its ROD not long after they were published. The minutes of an internal June 2002 meeting preparing for the SEIS indicate that “the PEIS does not contain specific language about why each of the five sites was selected.” The Army held seven scoping meetings between April 16 and 30, 2002, five on Oahu. ‘Ilio’Ulaokalani Coalition v. Rumsfeld, 369 F.Supp.2d 1246, 1253 (D.Haw.2005) Plaintiffs were barred from arguing the insufficiency of the alternatives considered in the PEIS because they had not submitted comments to the Army. Plaintiffs have not waived their right to challenge the sufficiency of the Army's consideration of reasonable alternatives. The Army had independent knowledge of the very issue that concerns Plaintiffs in this case, such that “there is no need for a commentator to point them out specifically in order to preserve its ability to challenge a proposed action” An agency decision may be set aside if it is “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.” The Army adopted a “tiered” approach to its compliance with NEPA, preparing a programmatic EIS followed by a site-specific EIS. Friends of Southeast's Future v. Morrison, 153 F.3d 1059, 1065 (9th Cir.1998), rev'd on other grounds, 490 U.S. 332, 109 S. Ct.1835, 104 L.Ed.2d 351 (1989), aff'd on remand, 879 F. 2d 705 (9rd Cir.1989) The court found that the existence of reasonable but unexamined alternatives renders an EIS inadequate. The Army settled on transformation of the 2nd Brigade in Hawaii in the PEIS. It reached this decision with no analysis of the environmental impacts or of reasonable alternatives to such a transformation. The Army violated NEPA by not considering alternatives that include transformation outside of Hawaii. It then leaps to the assumption that transformation in Hawaii or no action are the only alternatives. This is where the impermissible “narrowing” takes place. The Army argues that the record demonstrates that transformation of the 2nd Brigade in Hawaii is of strategic importance. Other locations in the United States with proximity to the Pacific Rim have been designated for early transformation. The Army had already started transformation of brigades at Fort Lewis, Washington. KLOA consists of 23,348 acres on the western slope of the Ko’olau Mountain Range, of which 5,310 acres are suitable for maneuver training activities. Appellee argues that the Army's assertion that Hawaii offers unique training areas for the 2nd Brigade once it has been transformed into a Stryker Brigade is “fully consistent with the actual training terrain available” The purpose and need of the Army's overall transformation is to modernize its brigade units as quickly and efficiently as possible, while maintaining combat readiness. The Army reasonably decided such transformation would proceed “in place,” i.e., at each brigade's present base location. The plaintiffs failed to raise their “concerns” through the prescribed administrative process and should therefore not be granted relief when they arrive at the federal courts. Plaintiffs' argument that the Army had to consider relocation of the 2nd Brigade ignores (and fails to challenge) the elephant in the living room. The Army had already determined that to achieve its purpose and need, transformation of all units, including the2nd Brigade in Hawaii, would be accomplished “in place.” Each of the seventy brigade-sized units would be transformed, one at a time, at Camp X. Equipping and transforming a Stryker Brigade Combat Team takes two years, plus an additional period to reach Final Operational Capability. The Army chose to foreclose a more circuitous route to transformation in the PEIS. The AEC's Licensing Board granted a permit for construction of the plants and its Appeal Board affirmed. Saginaw moved to have the AEC clarify its ruling and reopen proceedings on the power plants. The Supreme Court reversed the decision and remanded for further proceedings. In Department of Transportation v. Public Citizen, 541 U.S. 752, 124 S. Ct.2204, 159 L.Ed.2d 60 (2004), the Supreme Court unanimously reaffirmed its view that, under NEPA, would-be intervenors must participate meaningfully in agency proceedings. The majority is correct that the court refused to adopt a “broad rule which would require participation in agency proceedings as a condition precedent to seeking judicial review of an agency decision.” But the majority's insistence to the contrary, Kunaknana v. Clark, 742 F.2d 1145 (9th Cir 1984), does not require a different result here. Plaintiffs have not identified any exceptional circumstances warranting their excusal from Vermont Yankee's requirement. In Kunaknana, the exceptional circumstances that justified the court's carving out an exception to the Vermont Yankee rule was to effectuate Congress's special protection for Eskimos in ANILCA. The Army's SEIS states its purpose as to assist in bringing the Army's Interim Force to operational capability and to provide realistic field training in Hawai’i. The Army also met its obligation in the SEIS to consider reasonable alternatives to the proposed action of transforming the 2nd Brigade in Hawaii. Selection of the no-action alternative would have caused the 2nd Brigade not to be transformed into a Stryker brigade. Because this option had substantially similar environmental consequences as full relocation, the Army did not also separately have to consider relocation of the2nd Brigade. The Army's consideration of these alternatives establishes that the Army looked at reasonable alternatives to transformation in Hawaii. “The PEIS leaves us short on alternatives.The only alternatives we have are no action versus action.”  Timothy Julius commented that the “EIS is woefully inadequate:  The alternatives are meaningless.Where is the ‘analysis' of installations?”

Luis Rivera–Melndez worked at Pfizer's pharmaceutical manufacturing facility in Barceloneta, Puerto Rico in 1994. Rivera received several promotions, including a 2004 promotion to Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient (“API”) Group Leader. On October 11, 2008, Rivera received notice that he was being called to active duty in Iraq. He promptly notified Pfizer’s Senior Human Resources Specialist that he needed to take military leave. Rivera commenced his active duty service on December 5, 2008. His tour of duty concluded on October 21, 2009. In February 2009, Pfizer restructured its API Department and eliminated the API Group Leader position held by Rivera. Rivera returned to Rivera alleged that he was entitled to be rehired to a supervisory (i.e., the API Team Leader) position upon his return from active duty. Pfizer moved for summary judgment on August 23, 2011. The district court granted Pfizer's motion as to nearly all of Rivera's USERRA claims. In some cases, for example, the escalator principle could deliver an employee into “layoff status” if the “employee's seniority or job classification would have resulted in the employee being laid off during the period of service, and the layoff continued after the date of reemployment” The Department of Labor rejected these suggestions. USERRA affords broad remedies to a returning servicemember who is entitled to reemployment. The court also misinterpreted the regulations governing USERRA. The court did not apply the escalator principle and the reasonable certainty test to the API Team Leader position. The district court's analysis of Rivera's claim cannot stand on its fundamental misapprehension of the correct legal standard.

Angel A. Vega-Colón brought suit against his employer, Wyeth Pharmaceuticals.Vega contends that Wyeth discriminated and retaliated against him based on his military service.The district court granted summary judgment in favor of Wyeth, and Vega timely appealed.After careful consideration, we reverse in part and affirm in part. Wyeth moved for summary judgment on all of these claims, and shortly before trial its motion was granted.Final judgment was entered in Wyeth's favor and Vega timely appealed. USERRA is to encourage non-career military service, minimize disruption based on this service, and prevent discrimination against service members. Vega avers that Wyeth's failure to hire him for the reliability engineer position violated USERRA. The district court found this date to be November 2006. The burden is on Vega to make an initial showing that his military status “was at least a motivating or substantial factor in [Wyeth's] action” Vega contends that his level two 2006 performance rating, which resulted in his being placed on a PIP, was given in violation of USERRA. Wyeth's employee relations director put forth affidavit evidence that employees who received a low performance rating were not eligible to apply to other internal positions until the PIP was completed. The PIP itself documented Vega's various employee performance issues. The PIP itself stated that although Vega completed the set goals, it was being extended because of: (1) an email Vega sent in which he described a supervisor in a disrespectful manner; (2) a letter Vega improperly solicited his co-workers to sign attesting to his job performance; and (3) Vega's authorized leave. Vega testified that one of his supervisors, Andrew Espejo (“Espejo”), informed him that he did not pass the PIP because his performance was affected by his military service. Vega alleges that dating back to October 2006, he was subjected to comments and name calling by various Wyeth supervisors, related to his military service. Vega's restricted access to the plant cannot be deemed a denial of a “benefit of employment” because he was on leave at the time and had no need to access the plant. Vega filed a VETS complaint in March 2007. Wyeth presented evidence, including an affidavit from its human resources director and the entire VETS file, which established that it did not become aware of Vega's complaint until September 2007. Any retaliatory actions necessarily had to take place after this date. Vega has presented no evidence of Wyeth's process or criteria for awarding raises.

Soloman Robert Stanton is a member of the United States Navy. Soloman and Carol Adrianne Stanton married in August 1993, and they have a teenage son. The parties separated in 2005 and in March 2007 Soloman filed for dissolution of the marriage. Carol's income and expense declaration stated Soloman had stopped paying child and spousal support and she had just begun working. Federal Preemption Doctrine Is Inapplicable to California Support Law. Soloman asserts that because of the procedure the court adopted after setting aside the MSA on September 1, 2009 - scheduling a child support hearing the following day and then awarding spousal support on September 8 - he was unprepared to address the federal preemption doctrine. He submits the matter was not argued on the merits until December 3 and 23, 2009. Soloman cites federal statutory definitions of military “pay” as including “basic pay, special pay, retainer pay, incentive pay, retired pay, and equivalent pay.” He also cites a provision of the Internal Revenue Code that states, “Gross income shall not include any qualified military benefit” Soloman has not met his burden. In In re Marriage of Stokes (Or.Ct.App.2010) 228 P.3d 701 (Stokes ), an Oregon statute provided that in setting support the court should consider ‘[a]ll earnings, income and resources of each parent’ Stokes court held that BAH and BAS payments “fall within the broad category of ‘income from any source’” Soloman's reliance on Pegler v. Pegler (Ky.App.Ct.1995) 895 S.W.2d 580, is misplaced. Peger does not pertain to a statute similar to California support law, or to federal preemption. In Massey, supra, 68 A.D.3d at page 83, the court held the ‘federal statutory definition of ‘pay’ [37 U.S.C.§ 101(21) ] is not relevant to the issue’ Soloman's OSC for a reduction of child support claimed as a changed circumstance.Lexis 138, at *3.)III.Exclusion of Spousal Support from Carol's Gross Income.Soloman was awarded a reduction in child support by the court. The court ruled that the child support reduction was a change of circumstance.

NCIS agent found evidence of a crime committed by a civilian in the state and turned it over to civilian law enforcement officials. The civilian, Michael Dreyer, was prosecuted, convicted, and sentenced to eighteen years in prison. We hold that the NCIS agent's investigation constituted improper military enforcement of civilian laws. 10 U.S.C.§ 375. Congress has authorized certain exceptions to § 375, such as permitting the military to make equipment and facilities available to civilian law enforcement. We have previously recognized that, “[a]lthough the PCA does not directly reference the Navy,” “PCA-like restrictions” apply to the Navy. The regulations and policies implementing the PCA and § 375 “generally prohibit ‘direct’ military involvement in civilian law enforcement activities’ “ United States v. Hitchcock, 286 F.3d at 1069 (citations omitted).Prohibited direct assistance includes “[u]se of military personnel for surveillance or pursuit of individuals, or as undercover agents, informants, investigators, or interrogators” In Hitchcock, for example, the defendant “sold LSD to Lake, a U.S. Marine, who was, in turn, selling LSD to other military personnel” on his base. The lack of any reasonable connection between the military and the crimes that Agent Logan was investigating separates this case from those in which we have applied the independent military purpose exception. Navy peeked into every computer in Washington using peer-to-peer file sharing program, "Gnutella" U.S. Supreme Court rules that the exclusionary rule does not apply to Posse Comitatus violations. But this case amounts to the military acting as a national police force to investigate civilian law violations by civilians. In Dreyer's case, a jury convicted him of possession and distribution of child pornography. Judge: Exclusion “undeniably detracts from the truthfinding process and allows many who would otherwise be incarcerated to escape the consequences of their actions.” Judge: Courts have, since the 1970s, “imposed a more rigorous weighing of [the exclusionary rule's] costs and deterrence benefits” Agent Logan downloaded two images and a video, which, upon review, he confirmed contained child pornography. Subsequent searches of Dreyer's seized hard drives revealed several such files. Application of the exclusionary rule would suppress all evidence obtained by Agent Logan. The Supreme Court's warning against unnecessarily “setting the guilty free and the dangerous at large’ should give any jurist pause.

Teresita Dotson, Warren Fisher, and Annie Jones (collectively, “Defendants’) appeal their convictions for furnishing liquor to minors. Defendants were employed at McChord Air Force Base, Washington, by on-base establishments that sold alcohol. Each was charged separately with supplying liquor to persons under the age of 21. In both Clark and Debevoise, we held that state statutes were properly assimilated even though the defendant was also subject to punishment under certain articles of the Uniform Code of Military Justice (“UCMJ”) because those articles were not “of general applicability.” We conclude that no enactment of Congress precludes assimilation of § 66.44.270 under the ACA. The specific statute at issue is the type of prohibitory law we previously have deemed properly assimilated under the ACA. We agree with the government that declining to assimilate § 66.44.270 would “circumvent” the state’s purpose in penalizing the conduct at issue. We also conclude that assimilating the statute furthers the ACA's goal of uniformity.

Adel Hassan Hamad was detained at Guantanamo Bay as an enemy combatant. He seeks damages for his detention and his treatment from former Secretary of Defense Robert Gates. We conclude that 28 U.S.C.§ 2241(e) deprived the district court of subject-matter jurisdiction over Hamad's claims. Hamad is seeking damages from the United States military and civilian officers for his detention and treatment at Guantanamo. He argues that federal courts had jurisdiction under the then-effective version of the habeas corpus statute. Hamdi v. Rumsfeld, 542 U.S. 507, 510, 124 S.Ct.2633, 159 L.Ed.2d 578 (2004) § 2241 imposed two additional jurisdictional limitations: first, “no court, justice, or judge” could entertain “an application for a writ of habeas corpus filed by” a Guantanamo detainee. Second, no court could entertained “any other action against the United States or its agents relating to any aspect of the detention by the Department of Defense of an alien at Guantanamo Bay.” Hamad argues that we should read Boumediene as striking down all of § 2241(e), not just the subsection dealing with habeas petitions. We disagree. The logic and context of the opinion make clear that the Supreme Court was addressing only the subsection. Congressional intent serves as the basis for this severability test. Congress dealt separately with two different categories of actions that could be brought by Guantanamo detainees. Congress sought to bar alien detainees from applying for habeas corpus as reflected in 28 U.S.C.§ 2241(e)(1) Hamad argues that § 2241(e) is unconstitutional, because it deprives him of a federal forum to seek a remedy for violations of his constitutional rights. We disagree. Hamad is correct that the Supreme Court has avoided the question whether Congress may completely deny a plaintiff access to federal forum. But we can likewise avoid addressing this difficult issue, because Hamad seeks only money damages. Congress enacted § 2241(e) to limit and channel federal court review of detention and military commission decisions, not to impose any particular punishment on military detainees. Hamad argues that this distinction “serves no compelling legislative purpose and would not survive strict scrutiny” The Supreme Court has not determined whether the Fifth Amendment's protections even apply to Hamad. Gates became Secretary of Defense in December 2006. Because Hamad was transferred from Guantanamo in December 2007, Gates's tenure as Secretary overlapped with Hamad's detention at Guantanamo for one year. The ARB decision was heavily redacted and the explanation and reasoning for the panel's decision is blacked out. Statements on the floor of the House also indicate that Congress intended to limit detainee lawsuits. Hamad notes that Congress titled § 7 of the MCA as “Habeas Corpus Matters.” It is well-established that the title of a statute can be used to preserve a jurisdictional bar.

Charley D. Hill began working for Michelin in the early 1980s. Hill became a member of the United States Naval Reserves in 1995. In 1997 Hill took medical leave for a back injury. He returned to work in February 1998 with light duty restrictions. In April 1998 Hill was placed in a position in the “Q-Laboratory” section of “Service R.” Hill contends that he reported to the Q-Laboratories and that his new supervisor looked “distraught” when Hill informed him about Hill's Reserve obligations. Hill challenged the termination through Michelin's “fair treatment” program. Hill argued that other Michelin employees who made mistakes on their time cards were not terminated and that Michelin treated him differently because of his Reserve status. The review board ruled in favor of Michelin, concluding that Hill knew about the vacation day when he filled out the time card and that Hill intentionally falsified his time card. The Q-Laboratory operates under an eight-hour/seven-day rotating shift. The Service Z position required Hill to work some twelve-hour days during each shift. Just as a first shift job is generally preferred over a third shift job, most workers would also prefer a more regular schedule of shorter work days. Hill's complaint about the way the investigation was conducted and the result of the investigation are insufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact as to the relevant questions. We conclude that the transfer from the Q-Laboratory to Service Z must be considered a denial of a benefit of employment under USERRA. We reverse the district court's grant of summary judgment in favor of Michelin on Hill's transfer claim and remand for further proceedings.

The Uniformed Services Former Spouses' Protection Act (Act) gives states the option to classify a United States armed forces member's disposable military retirement pay as property divisible upon divorce.In this case current and retired members of the armed forces whose retirement pay has been divided in state divorce proceedings, and an association representing such members, sued the Secretary of Defense. McCarty v. McCarty, 453 U.S. 210, 101 S.Ct. 2728, 69 L.Ed.2d 589 (1981) The Court found an irreconcilable conflict between the federal statutes governing military retirement pay and state law that treated pay earned during marriage as spousal property. The plaintiffs are either retired armed service members drawing retirement pay or active duty members who will be eligible for this pay on retirement.On various dates between 1978 and 2003, these 58 individuals were all divorced.They are subject to state court divorce orders granting their former spouses a portion of their retirement pay.DFAS makes direct payments to the former spouses of at least some of the plaintiffs. In March 2005 the district court concluded that ULSG had standing to bring the equal protection, procedural due process, and uniformity claims. The court held that the Act violated the substantive component of the Due Process Clause by retroactively reaching the retirement pay of service members who joined before the Act's passage. The Rooker-Feldman doctrine, a corollary to this rule, prohibits “lower federal courts ” from exercising appellate jurisdiction over final state-court judgments. The plaintiffs seek a declaration that the Act is unconstitutional as applied to them. The Act applies to these plaintiffs by requiring the Armed Forces to transmit payments to qualifying former spouses pursuant to state court divorce decrees. A federal court declaration would invalidate the statutory basis for the federal payments mechanism. The Act does not exempt service members who joined the armed forces prior to its enactment from state court divorce decrees dividing their military retirement pay upon divorce. The plaintiffs allege that the lack of these exemptions retroactively alters the compensation they expected when hired. They contend that this retroactivity amounts to a violation of the substantive component of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. Only two plaintiffs in this case allege that they were divorced before the Act was signed into law in September 1982. The plaintiffs argue that the Act “give[s] rise to disparate treatment to service members” and that it “produces non-uniform results when implemented in state law. The plaintiffs argue that the Act violates their constitutional right to equal protection by distinguishing between persons based on three classifications. They allege that allowing the former husbands of female service members to receive a share of their retirement pay is “manifestly unfair,” as these former husbands in many cases have their own income. The plaintiffs argue that the Act unconstitutionally favors the former spouses over service members. The Act survives this rational basis review. Congress exhibited special concern for the personal and economic sacrifices that the spouse of a military service member makes to sustain the marriage. Congress could have properly concluded that those sacrifices were even more intense than the ordinary sacrifices associated with marriage to civilian employees. The Constitution simply does not compel Congress to provide for the service members a system entirely identical to the one created for other government officers. The decision whether to include a remarriage cutoff in the statute is properly left to Congress. If one purpose of allowing the former spouse to receive a portion of the military retirement pay is to provide economic support, Congress was not obligated to assume that the need for this support would always disappear. The Secretary contends that Endicott-Johnson forecloses the plaintiff's procedural due process attack because the state court divorce proceedings give members all the notice that they are due. The district court went on to examine the Act and the regulations using the balancing test first articulated in Mathews v. Eldridge, 424 U.S. 319, 335, 96 S. Ct.893. More intensive review would slow payments processing. DFAS sends monthly retirement pay distributions to about 54,000 former spouses. If DFAS did not want to increase case-processing time, it would have to hire additional staff, which would raise the government's total expenses for running the payments mechanism.

BWXT claims that it fired Rudolph Escher for doing work for his job in the Naval Reserves during company time and with company resources. Escher contends he was terminated in retaliation for complaints he made about BWXT's designation and accounting of his military leave time. The district court granted summary judgment to BWXT, and we AFFIRM. Escher argues that the district court overlooked that the investigation into his computer use was launched on August 17, less than 30 days after he filed his second complaint concerning BWXT's modified military leave policy. Escher's protected activities were not a motivating factor in the employer's action. Escher argues that the record creates a genuine issue of material facts as to whether his Naval Reserve work constituted “official U.S. Government use” or whether it was “incidental use.” Employment at BWXT is subject to the Employee Handbook: Standards of Business Conduct and Business Ethics.  BWXT has a long record showing that it maintains a generous military leave policy. The only other employee found to have used BWXT's computer system for personal gain was an African American female who was terminated after sending or receiving 200 e-mails regarding her hat-selling business. Escher's burden to show that the other employees' acts were of "comparable seriousness" to his own infraction. Once BWXT establishes its legitimate non-discriminatory reason, the burden of proof is on the employer to prove it is not discriminating against students. Anderson v.Anderson, 857 S.W.2d at 558-59; Provonsha v. Students Taking a Right Stand, Inc., 2007 WL 4232918, at *2-*4 (Tenn.Ct.App.Dec. 3, 2007); Robinson v. Nissan Motor Mfg.Corp., No. No., 2000 WL 320677, at*5-*6.

Salim Ahmed Hamdan was captured in Afghanistan in late November 2001. Hamdan's captors turned him over to the American military, which transported him to the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba. He was charged with conspiracy to commit attacks on civilians and civilian objects, murder and destruction of property by an unprivileged belligerent, and terrorism. In November 2004, Hamdan filed a petition for habeas corpus. The court held that Hamdan could not be tried by a military commission unless a competent tribunal determined that he was not a prisoner of war. Hamdan argues that a military commission has no jurisdiction over him and that any trial must be by court-martial. His claim falls within the exception to Councilman and is firmly supported by the Supreme Court's disposition of Quirin. Hamdan's jurisdictional challenge, by contrast, is not insubstantial, as our later discussion should demonstrate. Ex parte Quirin also stands solidly against Hamdan's argument. Court held that Congress had authorized military commissions through Article 15 of the Articles of War. Hamdan tried to distinguish Quirin and Yamashita on the ground that the military commissions there were in “war zones” while Guantanamo is far removed from the battlefield. In Eisentrager, German nationals, convicted by a military commission in China of violating the laws of war and imprisoned in Germany, sought writs of habeas corpus in federal district court. The Supreme Court, speaking through Justice Jackson, wrote in an alternative holding that the Convention was not judicially enforceable. Hamdan chose to ignore the decision in his brief. Hamdan argues that the habeas corpus statute permits courts to enforce the “treaty-based individual rights” set forth in the Geneva Convention. Eisentrager: That a court has jurisdiction over a claim does not mean the claim is valid. Hamdan also contends that a military commission trial would violate his rights under Article 102. The issue is not whether the commission may try Hamdan, but rather how it may try him. The district court interpreted the final qualifying clause to mean that military commissions must comply in all respects with the requirements of the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ) The UCMJ takes care to distinguish between “courts-martial” and “military commissions. Hamdan does not allege that the regulations establishing the present commission violate any of the pertinent provisions. The President found that Hamdan was not a prisoner of war under the Convention. Hamdan claims that AR 190-8 entitles him to have a “competent tribunal” determine his status. But we believe the military commission is such a tribunal.

Arvid Walter Brown, Jr. served in the United States Army during the first Persian Gulf War. He contracted Leishmaniasis, a parasitic disease common in certain parts of the Middle East that is spread by the bite of infected sand flies. Mr. Brown transmitted the disease to his wife via their daily personal and sexual contact, and to their two children in utero. He received medical care from the VA for various physical and psychological problems. White v. Baxter Healthcare Corp., 533 F.3d 381, 389 (6th Cir.2008) The district court granted summary judgment to the government on appellants' remaining claims for failure to warn and negligence. Appellants filed a motion for reconsideration, which the district court denied. This timely appeal followed. The court held that a physician-patient relationship is a special relationship that may give rise to a duty of reasonable care to third parties. The disputed question is whether Mrs. Brown and the two Brown children were foreseeable victims of any failure on the part of the VA to diagnose Mr. Brown with Leishmaniasis. A third party is a foreseeable victim “where [a] physician determines that his patient poses a serious threat of danger to a third person”

Rev.D. Philip Veitch, formerly a Lieutenant Commander in the Navy Chaplain Corps, appeals from the district court's grant of summary judgment to the Navy. His complaint alleged that he had been constructively discharged for unconstitutional reasons. The district court concluded that since Veitch had resigned voluntarily, he lacked standing to bring his constitutional claims. Veitch sued the Navy and several of its officers in federal district court in December 2000. The court granted summary judgment for defendants. Veitch then filed a six-count amended complaint alleging Free Speech, Establishment, and Free Exercise claims;  Claims for constructive discharge; and violations of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act. Veitch's argument seems to be that if the Navy's actions against him were unlawful, then they were per se coercive, whether or not those actions would actually force a reasonable person in Veitch's position to resign. For this extraordinary proposition, Veitch relies on one Court of Claims case, Roskos v. United States, 213 Ct.Cl.34, 549 F.2d 1386. The district court concluded that Veitch had not presented a triable issue of fact on the question of intolerable work conditions. Veitch argues that the district court ignored evidence of a hostile work environment and failed to give Veitch the inferences to which he is entitled as the nonmoving party on a motion for summary judgment. The NIG reported that Coyne, Buchmiller, and Gray's actions did not violate the Whistleblower Protection Statute. Veitch could not point the finger at his commanding officers to explain his disciplinary problems. Even if Zoeller's conclusions had been palpably unconstitutional, the fact that there was no retaliation for the EO Complaint means that Veitch's request would still have been denied. Rev.Veitch claims that his resignation was forced because of past discrimination-which he tolerated while engaging in an exchange of emails with Captain Buchmiller. The court noted that what would drive a reasonable person to resign “may vary with the character of the job for which the employee was hired and thus, indirectly, with the employee's skills” It held that the plaintiffs had presented no triable issue of fact on the question of constructive discharge.

Yaser Esam Hamdi filed a petition under 28 U.S.C.§ 2241 challenging the lawfulness of his confinement in the Norfolk Naval Brig. Hamdi apparently was born in Louisiana but left for Saudi Arabia when he was a small child. The petition alleges that Hamdi is a citizen of the United States who was residing in Afghanistan. Yaser Esam Hamdi is apparently an American citizen. He was also captured by allied forces in Afghanistan, a zone of active military operations. This dual status-that of American citizen and that of enemy combatant-raises important questions about the role of the courts in times of war. The Supreme Court has underscored this founding principle:   “The ultimate purpose of this separation of powers is to protect the liberty and security of the governed.” The courts must defend the “fundamental principles of liberty and justice which lie at the base of all our civil and political institutions,” the court says. Hamdi's petition falls squarely within the Great Writ's purview, since he is an American citizen challenging his summary detention for reasons of state necessity. The safeguards that all Americans have come to expect in criminal prosecutions do not translate neatly to the arena of armed conflict. Detention of enemy combatants serves at least two vital purposes. On this appeal, it is argued that Hamdi's detention is invalid even if the government's assertions were entirely accurate. The burden of the August 16 order would necessarily outweigh any benefits if, quite independent of the disputed factual issues, Hamdi were already entitled to relief. Hamdi argues that there is no congressional sanction for his incarceration and that § 4001(a) therefore prohibits his continued detention. Hamdi and amici contend that Article 5 of the Geneva Convention applies to Hamdi's case and requires an initial formal determination of his status as an enemy belligerent “by a competent tribunal. This argument falters also because theGeneva Convention is not self-executing, the court says. Hamdi's petition fails as a matter of law. The government should not be compelled to produce the materials described in the district court's August 16 order. The district court indicated that its production request might well be only an initial step in testing the factual basis of Hamdi's enemy combatant status. The court's order allows the government to redact “intelligence matters” from its responses. Hamdi's petition alleges that he was a resident of and seized in Afghanistan, a country in which hostilities were authorized and ongoing at the time of the seizure. The Government's response asserts that Hamdi is being detained pursuant to the Commander-in-Chief's Article II war powers. We think the government's assertion of the power to detain Hamdi under the war power is insufficient. Hamdi was captured in a zone of active combat operations in a foreign country. No evidentiary hearing or factual inquiry on our part is necessary or proper. Courts are ill-positioned to police the military's distinction between those in the arena of combat who should be detained and those who should not. Hamdi's citizenship rightfully entitles him to file this petition to challenge his detention, but the fact that he is a citizen does not affect the legality of his detention as an enemy combatant. Hamdi contends that his petition does not implicate military concerns because “the underlying claims in this case are designed to test the legality. of Hamdi's imprisonment in a naval brig in Norfolk, Virginia, not a military determination made overseas.” Hamdi is not “any American citizen alleged to be an enemy combatant” by the government. He is an American citizen captured and detained by American allied forces in a foreign theater of war during active hostilities. Hamdi's status as a citizen cannot displace our constitutional order or the place of the courts within the Framer's scheme.

David R. Hawkins appealed from the district court's order affirming the magistrate judge's denial of his motion to suppress evidence obtained as the result of the warrantless stop of his truck. Hawkins contends that the McClellan military police officers who stopped his truck violated his Fourth Amendment rights because the Government failed to present any evidence of an individualized suspicion of wrongdoing. The Government conceded that the stop of Hawkins's truck was a seizure, and that the officers had neither probable cause to arrest Hawkins nor an individualized suspicion of wrongdoing. To justify the warrantless stop, the Government introduced evidence that the base commander had ordered that vehicles entering or leaving McClellan be stopped for inspection. The stop was not subjectively intrusive. The Government's interest in maintaining national security and promoting public safety on base roadways outweighed the brief and limited intrusion resulting from stopping Hawkins at the Peacekeeper gate. We hold, therefore, that the stop of Hawkins and his truck was reasonable under the Fourth Amendment.

Wilfredo Romero was employed as an auditor at the Department of Defense (“DoD”).In December 2006, Mr. Romero was removed from his position for failing to maintain his Secret level security clearance. He appealed the removal action to the Merit Systems Protection Board (‘MSPB’).The MSPB affirmed the action.This court vacated the MSPb's decision and remanded for the M SPB to determine whether Mr.Romero could show harmful error resulting from the DoD's failure to follow its own procedures. Mr. Romero's employer requested that the DIA–CAF grant him SCI access. After conducting an investigation, the DIACAF informed Mr. Romero that a preliminary decision had been made to deny him clearance for access to SCI. The final decision indicated that the potential security risks included “the fact that your spouse is not a U.S. citizen, and is an accredited diplomat of the Government of Honduras” The administrative judge rejected Mr. Romero's due process argument because he had the opportunity to challenge the DIA–CAF's final decision and because the agency's regulations do not require an opportunity for review of a reciprocal acceptance of a security clearance revocation. The MSPB administrative judge again affirmed the DoD's action. Mr. Romero contends that the MSPB committed legal error by misapplying the statutes and regulations defining procedures for security clearance determinations. He argues that the DIASAB did not explicitly revoke his Secret clearance. The government counters that DoD regulations plainly permit DoD components like the WHS to designate other components to revoke security clearances. Mr. Romero contends that this result is unjust because different standards apply for access to SCI and eligibility for a Secret security clearance. While this is partially true, this argument misses the mark because there are standards under the common adjudicative guidelines that apply to both. The MSPB's conclusion that the DIA–CAF was authorized to revoke Mr. Romero's security clearance is correct as a matter of law and supported by substantial evidence.

Rothe Development Corporation (“Rothe”) appeals from the judgment of the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas. The government urges that we lack jurisdiction over this constitutional issue because it is unripe for adjudication. We hold that we do have jurisdiction to consider the facial constitutionality of the present reauthorization of section 1207. Rothe I, 49 F.Supp.2d at 953-54. The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the government. In Rothe III, we reversed the district court's judgment, holding that the court did not properly apply strict scrutiny in analyzing the constitutionality of section 1207. The court also denied Rothe's request for attorney fees. Rothe's claim to an award of the 1998 contract is moot because the contract was directed to the provision of computer-related services over a specific time period that has now passed. The government also contends that the court lacks jurisdiction to consider Rothe's claim that section 1207, as presently reauthorized, is facially unconstitutional. The government's argument is based on the procedural history of this case on remand. Rothe contends that the district court's findings and legal analysis do not support a holding that the present reauthorization of section 1207 is facially constitutional. The government argues that remand is required to develop the record so that legally sufficient findings can be made. We find it troubling that the government appears to have argued in favor of the very narrowing that it now claims to be erroneous. The government's claim that it was prevented from introducing evidence is weakened by its failure to cite in its appellate briefing to any specific evidence it would have introduced. Both parties would have been well-served to request clarification from the district court before submitting their summary judgment motions. We conclude that the matter must be remanded to allow both sides a fair opportunity to obtain and present Congressional evidence and arguments.

Kurtis Armann served as a private in the United States Army and was stationed in Germany.In October 1998, he attempted to kill Private Toni Bell by shooting her.Armann and Bell had previously entered into an agreement in which Bell would pay Armann to kill Bell's in-laws.When Bell backed out of the agreement and demonstrated reluctance to pay, Armann planned to kill her. Armann filed a petition for review in the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces (CAAF) On October 11, 2001, he filed a supplement in which he asserted the same three arguments previously raised in his principal brief to the ACCA. Armann for the first time asserted that he was mentally incompetent at the time of plea and sentencing due to the medications he had taken. Armann, 2007 WL 1576407, at *6. The District Court agreed with the Magistrate Judge that 28 U.S.C.§ 2254(d) set forth the appropriate scope of review for Armann's claims. The Government argues that the District Court misinterpreted this Court's decision in Brosius v. Warden when it applied the state-prisoner habeas standard, § 2254, to Armann. After exhausting all military remedies, they petitioned for habeas corpus relief in federal district court. The district court dismissed the petitions, basing the dismissal on its finding that the military courts had jurisdiction. The Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal, but gave the petitions “full consideration on their merits,” a broader scope of review than previously afforded. Brosius affirms the conviction of Boumediene v. Bush, 128 S. Ct. 2229, 2286, 171 L.Ed.2d 41 (2008) (Roberts, C.J., dissenting) The scope of federal habeas review is traditionally more limited in some contexts than in others, depending on the status of the detainee. On appeal, we affirmed the district court's order denying habeas relief, Brosius, 278 F.3d at 250, but based our reasoning on different grounds. We interpreted Burns as holding “that in considering a. constitutional claim involving a pure question of law or a mixed question of. law and fact, a federal court may not exercise de novo review’  . We then stated: “[W]e will assume-but solely for the sake of argument-that we may review determinations made by the military courts in this case as if they were determination made by state courts” A federal court's "limited function" in reviewing a servicemember's habeas petition is to determine whether the military courts have “dealt fully and fairly with an allegation raised in that application.” The CAAF noted that it was deciding the appropriate standard “for collateral review within the military justice system” Armann had sufficient opportunity to raise his competency claim during the court-martial. The Board of Review discussed only the “colorably creditable” claims. The Court of Military Appeals denied, in a single-sentence order, the petition for grant of review of the Board's decision. Armann argued that the types, amounts, and combination of medications that he was made to take while incarcerated resulted in him being involuntary intoxicated during his guilty plea trial. In its opposition to Armann's motion to attach exhibits, the Government observed that Armann asserted in his Statement and Verification that the medications were not relevant to his new trial petition. The Government's failure to fully brief the competency issue does not preclude a finding that the CAAF fully considered Arman's detailed arguments. Only on appeal to the CAAF did Armann, for the first time, raise the mental competency issue. The CAAF had discretion whether to grant or deny Armann's petition for review, see 10 U.S.C.§ 867, but chose to grant it nevertheless. The military process allows a defendant to raise questions about competency on appeal that were not previously asserted at trial.

Robert Clary joined the United States Navy on June 2, 1978 and remained on active duty until May 31, 1994.In 1990, Mr. Clary began an extra-marital relationship with the woman that is currently his wife. He received his first non-judicial punishment (“Mast”) and a letter of reprimand for conduct unbecoming an officer in 1991. In 1992, he received a second Mast for adultery and failure to obey an order. A Board of Officers convened and determined that sufficient evidence of misconduct and substandard performance existed to require him to “show cause” for retention in the Navy. In 1993, he failed for a second time to An officer removed from active duty who is required to be separated for failure of selection (FOS) for promotion to the next higher grade may apply for TERA. The United States filed this appeal over which we have jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C.§ 1295(a)(3).II. The primary issue in this appeal is the interrelationship between 10 U.s.C’s§ 1186 and TERA, a temporary force reduction tool. Section 1186(b)(1) is a mandatory statute requiring retirement pay for an officer if he or she is “eligible for voluntary retirement under any provision of law.” The dispute centers on whether eligibility under TERA requires explicit approval by the Navy. The Navy's policy as expressed by NAVADMIN 111/93 established Mr. Clary's eligibility pursuant to TERA. The Navy's NAVADMIN 111/93 implemented a temporary early retirement authority (TERA) authorized until 30 Sep 95 to help facilitate personnel drawdown. The government argues that this holding effectively grants officers who are subject to separation, by reason of misconduct or substandard performance, greater rights than those who otherwise voluntarily leave the service. Mr. Clary points to no explicit waiver of sovereign immunity allowing recovery of back pay for recovery of interest. In 1992, Congress granted the service secretaries temporary authority to offer early retirement to selected service members with at least 15 years of active duty service. Mr. Clary was not “eligible for retirement” at the time he was removed, and he therefore was not entitled to the retirement benefits awarded him by the Court of Federal Claims.

Donald L. Wagner (“Wagner”) appeals from the judgment of the United States Court of Federal Claims, which held that the decision of the Army Board for Correction of Military Records (‘ABCMR’) was not arbitrary, capricious, contrary to law, or unsupported by substantial evidence. The Court of Federal Claims denied Wagner's motion and granted the Army's cross-motion for judgment on the agency record. The court disagreed with Wagner that the ABCMR's conclusion was based on pure speculation over what the Secretary would have done if the regulation had been followed. Geoffrey Engels, like Sanders, was an officer in the Air Force when he was twice passed over for promotion by selection boards. The Court of Claims found that Engels had successfully demonstrated that the error in his records was not harmless and ordered his reinstatement. The second line of cases involves procedural errors regarding the composition of military selection boards and holds that, in these instances, harmless error review is inapplicable. The court in Doyle articulated two justifications for refusing to apply the harmless error rule:  (1) avoiding the erosion of essential components of a fair trial; and (2) the inability of a reviewing body to assess the magnitude of the error. The court in Evensen also explained that fundamental errors are not limited to statutory procedural error, but may also result from violations of regulations and even internal operating procedures. I respectfully dissent from the majority's holding that the decision of the Department of the Army Active Duty Board (“DAADB”) on the merits must be set aside. The proceeding was not properly initiated by the Secretary, but instead was initiated by a Personnel Management Officer at the Army's Full Time Support and Management Center. Even in the grand jury context, improper grand jury proceedings do not normally require setting aside a petit jury verdict of conviction.

Elysee Theagene is a native of Haiti who was admitted to the United States in April 1974, when he was six years old, as a lawful permanent resident. He never applied for naturalization as a United States citizen, but served in the U.S. Navy between 1989 and 1993 and participated in combat operations during the first Gulf War. In 1998, he was convicted of first degree residential burglary in California, and sentenced to imprisonment for a term of four years. In 2000, an Immigration Judge (“IJ”) found him removable as a result of his burglary conviction. In 2003, he appealed the decision of the IJ to the Board of Immigration Appeals (� In Moussa v. INS, 302 F.3d 823 (8th Cir.2002), the Eighth Circuit rejected the government's argument that the jurisdictional nature of 8 U.S.C.§ 1252(d)(1) precluded the court from considering petitioner's nationality claim. Theagene claims United States nationality based on his service in the United States military during the first Gulf War. Theagene conceded in his administrative proceedings that he had no evidence that his family had ever been persecuted. Theagene's former service in the United States military is not itself sufficient to prove nationality. He could have avoided the removal order, despite his aggravated felony, merely by establishing that he was not an alien. In Moussa v. INS,16 the Eighth Circuit case on which the majority relies, the petitioner claimed all the way through his administrative proceedings that he was not subject to removal because he was a citizen. This is because if he were not an alien, the IJ and BIA would have lacked jurisdiction over his person, and their decisions would be a nullity. Taniguchi could properly have brought her “patently frivolous” claim to citizenship under § 1252(b)(5), and thus, could have preserved her habeas claim.Rather, the petitioner sought habea relief, which was denied because of her failure to exhaust remedies by not bringing her citizenship claim.

This case is the fifth in a series of related actions challenging the United States Secretary of State's designation of the Mojahedin-e Khalq Organization (MEK) and its aliases as a Foreign Terrorist Organization (FTO) The MEK has challenged its FTO status before this court three times. In the other three cases, including both petitions for review following remand in NCRI I, the court denied the petitioners' challenges. The PMOI now seeks review of the Secretary's decision. The review “sounds like the familiar procedure normally employed by the Congress to afford due process in administrative proceedings” and is “reminiscent of other administrative review.” NCRI I, 251 F.3d at 196-97. The review applies only to the first and second requirements, namely, that the organization is foreign and that it engages in terrorism or terrorist activity or retains the capability and intent to do so. We have held that the third requirement-that the organization's activities threaten U.S. national security-presents an unreviewable political question. The PMOI argued that the 2003 Redesignation should be revoked because of its dramatically changed circumstances since the Secretary's and this court's last reviews. It submitted evidence to the Secretary of State of its changed circumstances, asserting that, since its initial FTO designation in 1997, it had ceased its military campaign against the Iranian regime and renounced violence in 2001. The Secretary denied the petition and published its denial in the Federal Register on January 12, 2009. The PMOI filed a timely petition for review on February 11, 2009 under 8 U.S.C.§ 1189(c). It asks us to vacate the Secretary's decision and remand with instructions to revoke its FTO designation based on a lack of substantial support in the record. Alternatively, the PMOi says the Secretary did not comply with the due process requirements set forth in our earlier decisions. The standard of review is the same under both versions of the statute whether we review a “designation,” a ‘redesignation’ or a � “petition for revocation.” See id.§ 1189(a)(4)(B) (2003) (redesignedation appropriate if “relevant circumstances” initially warranting designation “still exist”) with id.¶ 1189 (a)(6) (revocation appropriate if circumstances that were the basis for the designation have changed in such a manner as to warrant revocation) In other instances, the Secretary cited a source that it seemed to regard as credible but did not indicate to what part of the statute the source's information was relevant. It is unclear whether the Secretary believes that fundraising under false pretenses is direct evidence of terrorist activity or instead bears on the PMOI's “capability” to engage in terrorist activity.

Jason Carl Kennedy was disenrolled from the Navy Reserve Officer Training Corps (NROTC) program at George Washington University. He failed to complete the required course at the Officer Candidate School (OCS) in Quantico, VA. Mr. Kennedy challenged his disenrollment by suit in the United States Court of Federal Claims. Mr. Kennedy stopped receiving scholarship benefit payments in August of 2006. In March 2007, the Commanding General of the Marine Corps Recruiting Command executed a letter to the GWU NROTC Unit ordering that Mr. Kennedy be disenrolled from the Unit. The U.S. filed a motion on December 20, 2013, to send the case to the BCNR. The BCNR issued its decision on October 15, 2014. Mr. Kennedy argued that the Navy failed to conduct a required medical examination before disenrolling him, thus violating statutory and regulatory rights. He argued that he had been denied the right to appear before the August 17 PRB, again with the effect of undermining the legality of his disenrollment. The Court of Federal Claims concluded that each of these arguments lacked merit. Mr. Kennedy's disenrollment was not the first thing that came to mind when he was asked to look at the list of items. Mr. Kennedy was required to complete the list before he was able to begin his search for the items. The list includes items such as the number of feet, number of inches, and number of miles. Mr. Kennedy was expelled from campus housing in November 2005 after an altercation with his roommate, an attempt to fling himself out of a window, and psychological counseling. Following reports by his platoon, company, and battalion commanders of emotional instability, Mr. Kennedy appeared before a Commanding Officer's Board at Quantico on June 22, 2006. The D.C.Circuit ruled that the disenrollment recommendation of the Performance Review Board, made in view of his discharge from Officer Candidate School without permission to reapply, was harmful error warranting judicial intervention.

Jose Padilla was convicted of conspiring with others within the United States to support al Qaeda's global campaign of terror. Padilla claims that he was repeatedly abused, threatened with torture, deprived of basic necessities, and unjustifiably cut off from access to the outside world. The Supreme Court vacated Padilla's petition that should have been filed in South Carolina. Padilla claims that, as a U.S. citizen captured within the United States, he was unconstitutionally designated as an enemy combatant.Padilla alleges a range of constitutional violations stemming from his ensuing military detention.As relief, Padilla seeks a declaration that his designation, military detention, and treatment in custody were unconstitutional. In the forty years since Bivens, the Supreme Court has monitored the limits of judicial competence to design implied remedies. The Constitution delegates authority over military affairs to Congress and to the President as Commander in Chief. The Court has itself “consistently refused to extend Biven liability to any new context or new category of defendants” Padilla V, 423 F.3d 386, 555 U.S. 7, 24, 26 (2008) The need to hesitate before using Bivens actions to stake out a role for the judicial branch seems clear. It is settled that courts “accord the President the deference that is his when he acts pursuant to a broad delegation of authority from Congress” The complaint asserts that in May 2004, defendant Rumsfeld ordered the Naval Inspector General, Vice Admiral Albert T. Church, to conduct a review of detentions at the Naval Consolidated Brig where Padilla was held. The complaint seeks quite candidly to have the judiciary review and disapprove sensitive military decisions made after extensive deliberations within the executive branch. Padilla asks us to ignore ample evidence that “congressional inaction has not been inadvertent,” he writes. He argues that Congress acted with a “greater ability to evaluate the broader ramifications of a remedial scheme” than we possess. The problems of administrability here are at least two-fold. Padilla argues that a Bivens action will not require courts to do much more than they are doing already. He argues that cases like Stanley and Chappell do not apply to him because he is not a member of the armed forces. The source of hesitation is the nature of the suit and the consequences flowing from it, not just the identity of the plaintiff. Padilla challenged his military detention in habeas corpus proceedings before five different courts. He also brought suit under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act. The Supreme Court has warned that “the full protections that accompany challenges to detentions in other settings may prove unworkable and inappropriate in the enemy-combatant setting.” Padilla contends that RFRA allows him to challenge circumstances of his military detention. Supreme Court: RFRA does not authorize tort suits by members of the military for injuries sustained while engaged in military service. Court: It would run counter to basic notions of notice and fair warning to hold that personal liability in such an unsettled area of law. RFRA was an effort to reverse the Supreme Court's denial of a free exercise claim in Emp't Div., Dep't of HumResof Oregon v. Smith, 494 U.S. 872 (1990) (holding that the Free Exercise Clause does not require accommodation of a religious practice) RFRA does not create a cause of action allowing military regulations to be challenged in civilian courts. Padilla's final claim is that the district court erred in concluding that he lacked standing to seek an order enjoining the government from designating him as an enemy combatant in the future. The standing doctrine gives practical effect to the Constitution's “fundamental limits on federal judicial power in our system of government”

Al-Haramain Islamic Foundation, a designated terrorist organization, and two of its attorneys brought suit against President Bush and other executive branch agencies and officials. They claimed that they were subject to warrantless electronic surveillance in 2004 in violation of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The government countered that the suit is foreclosed by the state secrets privilege, an evidentiary privilege that protects national security and military information. Al-Haramain is a Muslim charity which is active in more than 50 countries. Its activities include building mosques and maintaining various development and education programs. The U.N. Security Council has identified Al- Haramain as an entity belonging to or associated with Al Qaeda. The government moved to dismiss the case, or in the alternative, for summary judgment, on the basis of state secrets privilege. The state secrets privilege is a common law evidentiary privilege that permits the government to bar the disclosure of information if “there is a reasonable danger” that disclosure will “expose military matters which, in the interest of national security, should not be divulged”  United States v. Reynolds, 345 U.S. 1, 10, 73 S. Ct.528, 97 L.Ed.727 (1953). The privilege is not to be lightly invoked. Al-Haramain challenges warrantless surveillance authorized under the TSP. Until disclosure of the program in 2005, the program and its details were a highly prized government secret. Attorney General Gonzales confirmed that surveillance occurred without FISA warrants. U.S. citizens could be surveilled only if they communicated with a suspected or known terrorist. Khaled El-Masri, a German citizen of Lebanese descent, brought claims stemming from injuries allegedly received during his detention under the Central Intelligence Agency's (“CIA”) “extraordinary rendition” program. The government defended the suit on the basis of the state secrets privilege. The Fourth Circuit upheld the government's assertion of thestate secrets privilege and dismissed the action. Al-Haramain's case does involve privileged information, but that fact alone does not render the very subject matter of the action a state secret. We affirm the district court's denial of dismissal on that basis. Two claims of privilege are at issue, although they are intertwined and refer generally to both under the rubric of the Sealed Document. Al-Haramain says he is subject to NSA surveillance. The government says the Sealed Document is protected by the state secrets privilege. The court says the privilege is exceptionally well documented. The panel says the district court erred in forging an unusual path forward in this litigation. Al-Haramain cannot establish that it suffered injury in fact, a “concrete and particularized” injury, because the Sealed Document is protected by the state secrets privilege. It is not sufficient to speculate that it might be subject to surveillance under the TSP simply because it has been designated a ‘Specially Designated Global Terrorist'

Doe, an eight-year veteran of the Army, enlisted for a one-year term in the California State National Guard and the Army Reserve National Guard of the United States. On July 23, 2004, Doe's unit received orders to active-duty in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. On January 27, 2005, in response to a medical condition, Doe received new orders retaining him on active duty under 10 U.S.C.§ 12301(d). On January 31, 2005 he received his present assignment to the California Medical Community Based Health Care Organization in Sacramento, California. The President declared a national emergency on September 14, 2001. In the same proclamation, he invoked his power under 10 U.S.C.§ 12305 to activate members of the Army National Guard. On July 23, 2004, Doe's unit was activated during the national emergency. Doe argues that his enlistment extension violates his Fifth Amendment rights. The Supreme Court has recognized that under Article I, Congress has wide latitude in delegating its powers. The President's power to extend enlistments is expressly limited, and therefore, if exercised within these limits, cannot be said to be arbitrary. We conclude that 10 U.S.C.§ 12305 is not an unconstitutional delegation of congressional authority. Doe argues that his involuntary enlistment extension violates 10 U.S.C.§ 12407(a) He argues that the “Try One” moniker was misleading and precluded Doe from receiving requisite notice. Nothing in the record suggests Doe was misled or that the government made misrepresentations.

Cheryl Francis brought suit against her former employer, Booz, Allen & Hamilton, Inc. (“BAH”), alleging discrimination, wrongful termination, and retaliation.The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment.On April 22, 2005, the district court granted summary judgment to BAH on all counts, denying Francis' motion and dismissing her complaint with prejudice. Less than two weeks after receiving the Notice of Probation, Francis left the office without authorization in order to attend to a customer at an off-site location. On December 15, 2003, BAH terminated Francis' employment, and this action followed. Francis brings three claims under USERRA, which we will examine in turn. Section 4312 states that “any person whose absence from a position of employment is necessitated by reason of service in the uniformed services shall be entitled to the reemployment rights and benefits of [USERRA].” Francis argues that § 4312 protects her from discrimination with respect to the terms and conditions of employment after she has been rehired. BAH argues that the “reemployment” rights protected by Sections 4312 and 4313 apply only at the instant of reemployment. Francis contends that, after being reemployed as a Level II Senior Consultant, she was gradually given more Tier I work than she had pre-deployment and was no longer given any Tier III work. The district court responded to this argument, noting that Francis offers no support, beyond her own conclusory opinions, for the contention that her status and duties were changed. Francis argues that the district court erred in granting summary judgment to BAH on her claim of improper discharge. She contends that she presented evidence sufficient to create a dispute over whether BAH discharged her in violation of § 4316(c) The district court did not err in deciding this claim on summary judgment.

The Stolen Valor Act makes it a crime to falsely claim receipt of military decorations or medals and provides an enhanced penalty if the Congressional Medal of Honor is involved.Respondent pleaded guilty to a charge of falsely claiming that he had received the Medal of honor, but reserved his right to appeal his claim that the Act is unconstitutional. Justice Breyer, joined by Justice Kagan, concluded that because the Stolen Valor Act, as presently drafted, works disproportionate constitutional harm, it fails intermediate scrutiny, and thus violates the First Amendment. The Court also distinguished between an employer/employee agreement enforceable. pursuant to the FAA and union collective bargaining agreements. It is not evident from the statutory language that Congress intended to preclude arbitration by simply granting the possibility of a federal judicial forum. An agreement to arbitrate under the FAA is effectively a forum selection clause. An exclusive judicial forum is not a right protected by Chapter 43 of USERRA, nor is it within the scope of Section 4302(b) In Gilmer, the Court phrased the relevant inquiry as whether Congress had precluded “arbitration or other nonjudicial resolution” of claims. A portion of the 1994 legislative history of USERRA confirms Congressional intent to forbid resort to binding arbitration. Congress did not intend the Secretary of Labor or the Attorney General to be involved in every dispute brought under USERRA. The court below erred in refusing to compel arbitration of Garrett's USERRA dispute with Circuit City. The judgment is REVERSED and REMANDED for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.Enforcement of employment arbitration agreements does not disserve or impair the protections guaranteed byUSERRA.

Eliazer Madrigal-Valadez sought reversal of the district court's judgment that he was guilty of entering Fort Lee, a military installation, for a purpose prohibited by law. The courts have referred to this crime as a trespass. We conclude the placing of a sign, setting forth entrance requirements some distance from a public highway on the Fort Lee access road does not provide notice of the requirements to enter the military installation. Madrigal contends that the evidence was insufficient to demonstrate that he received notice of the entry requirements before he entered the Fort Lee military installation. The district court sentenced Madrigal to time served and ordered that upon his release from custody, he should be turned over to the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement for removal to Mexico. The Ninth Circuit affirmed the conviction of peace demonstrators who entered a military base without permission of the base commander. In United States v. Hall, 742 F.2d 1153, 1154 (9th Cir.1984), the Ninth Circuit said the defendants were warned by the sign, the five security guards, and the fence around the installation. Accordingly, contrary to district court's alternative holding, Madrigal's entry into the Fort Lee access road was not conduct that was prohibited by §’1325(a) or §‘1382.Because the evidence is insufficient to demonstrate that MadrigAl had notice of the requirements for entry before he drove onto the FortLee access road, we hold that the judgment must be reversed.
